DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of Mabel Kiyawasew, Pupil No. 0168, of the Stingray Lake No. Indian Residential School at Valois, who died at (place) on Dec. 8th 1941.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Form No. 414.

A. STATEMENT OF THE PRINCIPAL OF THE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

1. On what date did this pupil fall sick or suffer injury? Mabel fell ill with the measles on the 20th of October.

2. At what time of day? In the evening of October 20th.

3. When and to whom did he or she report this illness or accident? The same evening.

4. What means were taken to afford relief? Quarantine and rest in darkened apartments.

5. What medicines were used for this purpose and in what dose or quantity? Diet, cough syrup three times daily, aspirin every four hours when temperature was high, safe bathing, and cold linseed oil.

6. When was the doctor called? On the 18th of November.

7. If the pupil was removed to hospital, at what time was this done and by what means of transport? The pupil was removed to her home on the 17th of November at 4:00 P.M., comfortably arranged in a wagon.

8. If the pupil was not removed to hospital, what measures were taken for his or her care at the school? See No. 5.

9. Add any other useful information here.

Mabel fell ill with the measles, and then took broncho-pneumonia. Arrangements were made for her removal to the hospital but the parents objected. The above prescriptions were faithfully followed before and after the doctor's visit. Eggs and milk were included in the diet, and Mabel was occasionally rubbed with evaporated oil. She died on the 8th of December.

Principal.

Note: If the deceased pupil dies in hospital at a distance from the school, under the care of the physician or surgeon who attends him at the hospital, a clinical report of the patient's illness and death in the hospital is to be secured and attached to this memorandum.
B. STATEMENT OF THE PHYSICIAN WHO ATTENDED
THE DECEASED PUPIL

I attended Mabel Kiyawas on Nov 12, 1941.

The immediate cause of death was bronchopneumonia.

The contributory cause of death was measles.

Do you consider that the Principal of the School, and the members of the School staff exercised reasonable care and judgment in regard to the illness and death of this pupil? Yes.

Did they follow out your professional instructions? Yes.

If in either respect, you consider them to have been at fault, it is required that you express your carefully considered views as follows:

Most of the children at the school developed measles in October. On my visit on Nov 12, 1942, there were a number of other pupils ill with bronchopneumonia which they developed following measles.

[Signature]
M.D.

C. STATEMENT OF INDIAN AGENT

1. Having heard and read over the statements of the Principal and the Physician, do you consider that all essential circumstances relating to the death of:

No. 0168, - Nabel Keeshwahsee

have been recorded? Yes. If not, you are required to add here any further particulars which strike you as essential.

2. In this space record any recommendations which the Board consider should be made to the Department in relation to the health or safety of the pupils of this School.

Nil.

Chairman - Indian Agent.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6376, file 766-5, part 1)
Sir:

Rev. Father Fahler called on me a short time ago and stated that fire had totally destroyed the Indian Boarding school at Fort Vermilion.

He wished to know if the Department would see it's way clear to give some assistance towards the cost of re-furnishing the school, and submitted a list of articles required for this purpose, (said list herewith turned out).

I would recommend that these articles be provided as shown on list with the addition of 12 dozen pails making one dozen in all, because in my opinion it is very necessary in this instance where there is no up-to-date fire protective service, that there should be filled water-pails distributed throughout the building as a protection against a sudden out-break of fire.

Inspector Treaty No. 8.
Ottawa, March 31,, 1915.

Sir,

The Department having decided to come to the relief of the Fort Vermilion Boarding School, which was destroyed by fire a year ago this month, I have to request that you will be good enough to purchase the following articles and have them forwarded to the Principal of the school at the earliest opportunity:

- 15 bed stands and blankets
- 15 desks
- 1 dozen chairs.
- 1 clock.
- 1 large table
- 1 cooking range (large) and utensils
- 2 large heating stoves
- 1 dozen pails.

It might be well, if possible, for you to get in touch with the Principal or Rev. C. Palmer, provincial vicar of Athabasca, Edmonton, and get directions as to how these supplies should be sent. The cost of these articles should be within the neighbourhood of $500.00 and you will be enough to forward to the Department detailed vouchers, if any, for the purchases.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

One dozen pairs are being ordered, instead of the half dozen as asked for. Mr. Gard has been informed that it would be well for him to get in touch with either you or the Principal of the school and get directions as to how these supplies should be sent.

Sir:

Referring further to your letter of the 11th instant, enclosing a requisition for school supplies for the use of the Fort Vermilion Indian Residential School, it is noted that the Principal requests that 12 single desks and 2 front and 2 rear seats be supplied. Before considering this request, further particulars will have to be furnished as to the need for this number of desks. Fifteen desks were supplied this school in 1915 and 12 were supplied in 1919. The grant allowed is for 30 pupils only, and, if the desks which have been supplied are in good condition, it is not understood why the extra number now asked for is required. Please state the condition of the desks at present in use, and whether you would recommend that the number now asked for be supplied. As the funds at our disposal are limited, we are not prepared to supply more desks than are absolutely required to provide seating accommodation for the number of grant earning pupils allowed.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your circular, No. 87, with reference to
the question of fire protection in our school, I beg to advise
that the main residential building is adequately provided with
easily accessible fire escapes. The school building (10 x 26ft.)
in which the second story is used for the boys' dormitory, has only
one outside stair easy of access. If in your opinion this be
not sufficient, we shall have another stair constructed at the other
end of the building.

Fire fighting apparatus; such as extinguishers, ladders,
buckets etc. are kept in evidence in case of emergency. We have
six Grath Fire Extinguishers. We believe it would be prudent to
possess more extinguishers, but as these are expensive we must be
content with a limited number in our poor northern mission. If
the Department can be of assistance to us in this matter, the
service shall be greatly appreciated.

Yours truly,

Mr. Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Supt General,

My Dear Doctor Scott:

R.T. Ferrier will probably bring before you a few items which I have mentioned to him in a few letters which I have sent yesterday by the boat. This time, I wish to entertain you personally about the school of Fort Vermilion where I am presently and which I have thoroughly visited yesterday.

Some time ago, the Principal of this institution had requested me to present before you his urgent demand for the construction of a boys' wing and for other repairs. Being aware of financial circumstances and moreover not being totally conversant with the situation here I did not acquiesce to the Reverend Principal's demand. I believe I was wrong. I therefore came today to ask you if you would allow us to build a wing to provide extra accommodation for our boys. The sleeping, dining and recreation quarters would be sensibly enlarged and the girls' recreation room would also profit by the change. The Department has limited the capacity of the school to 25 children whilst we could easily find perhaps double that number.

A hot air furnace, paint, a couple of sewing machines, two or three washing machines, etc would also be required for the present building, the hot air furnace to replace the worn out one in the class room building and dormitory.

If the Department was not in a position to help us financially this year would you consider letting me borrow from the Bank an amount set by you and payable at a date also set by you. I insist in the matter because it is urgent and serious. I will leave here on the 22nd and expect to reach Grouard on the 27th inst.

Hoping to be favored with a good answer, I remain

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Vicar Apostolic of Grouard.
July 2, 1931.

Dear Bishop Guy:

I have Your Lordship's letter of the 16th ultimo, with reference to the urgent need for a boys' wing at the Vermilion Indian Residential School. There are no funds at the present time to satisfy this request, and, as I am very uncertain when such could be provided, I regret that the Department is not in a position to advise you.

I understand that the dormitories provide proper accommodation for a few more pupils and Mr. Ferrier tells me that he has arranged for a pupilage of 40 as from April first, last. This will relieve the situation somewhat.

I have reviewed the proposed expenditure and the appropriation to complete the St. Bruno's Indian Residential School improvements, and I believe there will be very little remaining after the accounts are paid, the present water supply system completed and the electric plant properly installed. I find, however, that, in all probability, we can supply the hot air furnace required for the classroom and dormitory building at Vermilion and, in addition, two sewing machines and two washing machines. In a few days, I will write to the Indian Agent, concerning where he should purchase the hot air furnace. Your Lordship may purchase two inexpensive washing machines and forward a certified account, in duplicate, direct to Ottawa. Two sewing machines will be ordered by the Department.

With warm personal regards,

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

GROUARD, ALTA
August 16th, 1932

My Dear Phil:

I suppose that in the Department in spite of Mr Ferrier's disappearance it is "business as usual" in the Department. I suppose however that there is a certain cast of gloom in the Office. You do not realize how often I think of the dear man for whom I had a real liking. Of course I must say that I have the same sentiments towards you and Mr Sutherland, that said to prevent any jealousy.

Now to the point. Sr Mary Stela of Fort Vermillion or rather Rev Fr Habay has written me about the desks that were refused to the school as per your letter of July 8th, 1932. I feel more than sorry in the matter as they are in absolute need of said desks in that school where we have spent so much last year in erecting a two-story building (annex of 50'x30' to the boy's building). Of course $1,200.00 are on the list of amounts voted but for the painting, heating and supplying bedding to the school. Could not the desks be included in the amount? The heating system costs around $470.00, the painting about the same, the beds (24) should, I presume, cost between $200.00 and $250.00. You could cram in the desks asked for. Don't you think?

If you are to take action wire order to Moyer's Edmonton with request to pay freight to Peace River and ship in time to catch the boat of Sept. 3rd.

Regarding the beds the Department has been dealing with Parkhill Bedding Edmonton whose manager is aware of the kind already supplied and you could also wire them in the matter for 24 beds and mattresses in order that same may be shipped on the boat of Sept. 3rd.

The typewriter has also been refused for above school. I am sorry I was not in Ottawa when such request was turned down. On account of the very special work done by the sister with her school publication I had prevailed upon Mr Ferrier to practically assure a typewriter and he had told me to write the sister in order to know the particular type she wanted. Can you reconsider your letter of July 6th?

Finally, I would ask you to add games and the books needed for supplementary reading. You
GROUARD, ALTA

would do us a favor by having same mailed in time to reach Vermilion by the boat leaving Peace River on Sept 3rd.

I am writing to you but I suppose Mr Sutherland is acting Superintendent. So, simply pass him my letter and tell him that the good words I have for you apply to him as well—he knows that—and the requests also.

Best regards to the office staff.

I will be around by the beginning of October with receipts for reimbursements for Grouard and other schools and of course with my list of requests for the coming year.

Yours very truly,

[Vicar apostolic of Grouard.]

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Christianson has forwarded a copy of your letter to him of the 12th instant, regarding the burning of the convent and hospital at Fort Vermilion.

No particulars as to the actual loss incurred have yet been received, other than the information in your letter referred to. It is noted that the boys' part of the school was saved and that there was no loss of life.

I shall be pleased to have a full report from you, as early as possible, stating the loss incurred as it affects the school. You should also state what arrangements were made by the Reverend Sisters in charge for the carrying on of the school work. Please advise the Department if it was necessary to send any of the pupils to their homes or if they have accommodation for the girls. If any pupils were sent home, their names and register numbers should be given.

It is noted that you have forwarded supplies of blankets, clothing, drugs, etc., Please inform us what further supplies are required and state the best arrangements that could be made to have them forwarded to the school. It is understood that the boats have now ceased running and it might be difficult to have freight forwarded.

In reporting on the fire, you should state how same occurred and give as full information as you can regarding the matter. The Department understands that mail facilities are uncertain at this time of the year, but we will await your report, giving the information requested at as early a date as it can be supplied.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 8th inst., No.405-12:

The Convent and the Hospital were burnt at 6 o'clock A.M. on October 7th. The School was saved (boy's part). Dr. Hammon and the nursing Sister managed to save their patients while the Sisters and the Father saved the children, some of them being still in bed. Everything was lost by the fire: furniture, clothes, blankets, stoves, &c.

As soon as I received the wire, Friday morning, I got two trucks and mustered up all the medical supplies, blankets, clothing, &c., I could get from the agency and the St. Bruno's and St. Bernard's Missions. Three small cases of the most needed medicines were sent, one from Dr. McIntyre, and two from the Mission. No list was kept as we had to rush to pack and get these supplies to Peace River the same night as the boat was leaving the next morning. I sent 25 blankets, 1 bale of underwear, drawers and shirts, 25 white shirts, 1 box hospital shoes, 1 bale kit bags and 30 brushes. The Missions have also sent blankets, clothing, 1 stove and various other supplies. All was loaded on time to leave Peace River on the 8th of October.

With reference to my wire of the 11th instant, the medicine supplies referred to by Dr. Hammon in his message to me were those sent by us since the fire, as the supplies received from Ottawa recently have been burnt.

I am today sending a Drug Requisition for the St. Theresa's Hospital, to the National Drug Company, Edmonton, as per your instructions. I am enclosing a copy of same for your information.

Your obedient servant,

"N.P.L'HEUREUX"

Fire Report.

Date of Fire, October 7th, 1932.
School, St. Henry Indian Residential.
Location, Fort Vermilion, Alberta.
Agency, Lesser Slave.
Reserve, Peace River.

The true origin of the fire will never be known. The flames were seen first in the kitchen. The only fire in that section of the house at the time was in the kitchen range. Whether the big fire actually originated there and then spread elsewhere, we do not know. The flames had made such headway when discovered, it was impossible to ascertain just how and where the fire had begun.

All patients in the hospital and some small children in the girls' dormitory were removed at once.

The opening of doors caused the flames to spread and mount upward at terrific speed. Fire extinguishers were used, but to no avail. In a few minutes the entire building containing the apartments for the Sisters, the Indian girls, the Chapel, the bakery, and the kitchens, together with the St. Anne's Hospital which adjoined it were a mass of flames and all hope of saving anything had to be abandoned.

The building in which are the two classrooms, the Boys' Hall, refectory and dormitory, was in great danger. The side exposed to the fire was badly scorched and the roof began to burn. With extreme effort and the assistance of a bucket brigade, axes and several hand pumps, the building was saved.
It is in this building that the Sisters and all the pupils are living at present. The Boys' section is 30 feet by 50 feet. The Girls' section is 25 feet by 50 feet. The second floor of this building is used for the dormitory.

All pupils enrolled were not present when the fire occurred, but of those who were, not one was sent home. Three pupils have returned to school since the fire and two new ones were admitted.

The pupils are all enjoying good health. Thomas Ashkabat, Beaver Indian of ten years, died on December 7th. He had been ill since last spring.

The classwork is carried on as usual. The pupils seem happy and contented and manifest lively interest in their work.

A temporary building of 34 by 46 feet is underway. It will be occupied by the Indian girls as soon as possible.

Joseph Halloway

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection of St. Henry's Roman Catholic Boarding School at Fort Vermilion. As the Department are aware, the school and hospital were burned down last fall, but a new school is under construction at the present time, and I am attaching hereto a snap of the building.

I found there were 66 children on the register, but only 56 were present at that time. The grades taught there are from I to V. Besides the above number there are also quite a few Halfbreeds attending the school.

After the fire last fall some of the outbuildings were converted into living quarters and the school authorities certainly did well to bring the children through the winter as they did. The new school is being partly used at the present time, but they expect to have it completed before fall.

My visit to this institution was on Sunday afternoon and I could not examine the classroom work, but I am sure from the children's work that I saw that good work is being done. The two

Dr. Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA,

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6376, file 766-5, part 1)
classrooms were well maintained and I am quite confident that the teachers in charge are very capable. The staff consists of the Rev. Principal, Joe. Habay; Asst. Principal, Father Deman, two lay brother and 10 Sisters of Providence.

BUILDINGS:

The new school building is a three story building, 34 X 46. The top is 30 feet from the ground. Besides this they have an old building 100 X 30 that is used as a dormitory and classroom. The laundry is a separate building: This is a terrible place,- an old dilapidated building and in very poor state of repair. The sister informed me that it was a very difficult matter to work there in the winter and I quite see that this is the case.

The grounds surrounding the buildings are excellent as it is situated right on the banks of the Peace River, which is one mile across at that point. This mission was started first in 1863, but has been permanently maintained since 1878. The first school was build in 1899: a frame building was erected in 1908 and was burned to the ground in 1914; rebuilt in 1917 and burned to the ground in 1932. The school owns 260 acres of land. At present they have under crop 15 acres of wheat, 35 acres of oats and 25 acres of barley as well as 20 acres of rye and about 3 acres in garden. They own 32 cattle, 22 horses, 25 pigs and 60 chickens. At the time I was there they were milking 8 cows, therefore the children received all the milk they required. The children all
looked well and this was born out by the results of an examination by the Doctor.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Indian Agencies,

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

RE: Grant to reimburse Church Authorities for erection of building for girls, Fort Vermilion Indian Residential School.

The girls' building was destroyed by fire on October 7, 1932. The church authorities, under the direction of His Lordship Bishop Guy, erected a new building for the girls during the past summer. This is a three-story frame building, 34' x 46'. The only contribution made by the Department was payment for 500 sacks of cement used in the foundation of the building. Bishop Guy authorized this undertaking. We have received no particulars regarding the cost of materials and labour in carrying out the work. During his recent visit, Bishop Guy made a request to be reimbursed to the extent of $5,000.00 towards the expenditure incurred by the church authorities.

Materials and equipment for the new building have been supplied as follows:

| Item                        | Quantity | Cost   |
|-----------------------------|----------|--------|
| 500 sacks of cement         |          | $475.00|
| Bake oven                   |          | $325.00|
| Sewing machines             |          | $119.22|
| Fire extinguishers and freight on same |          | $193.60|
| Blankets and sheeting       |          | $285.00|
| Beds and mattresses         |          | $602.00|
| Hotel range                 |          | $366.33|
| Teacher's desk              |          | $28.00 |

Total: $2,304.15

The mission at Fort Vermilion was started in 1863. The first school was built in 1899; a frame building was erected in 1908 and burned in 1914, rebuilt by the church in 1917 and burned on October 7, 1932. This is the building that has been erected, towards the cost of which Bishop Guy requests reimbursement to the amount stated above. His Lordship undertook the erection of the new girls' building without reference to the Department, and no promise was made him that a grant would be provide towards the cost. Grant is provided for 65 pupils at $150 per capita, less 10% during the present fiscal year. There is an enrolment of 33 boys and 33 girls.

Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
The girls' building at the Vermilion Indian Residential School, located at Fort Vermilion, northern Alberta, was totally destroyed by fire on October 7th, 1932. His Lordship the Bishop of Grouard erected a new building during the summer of 1933. It is a three storey frame building, 34 x 46 ft., and provides accommodation for 55 girls and the Reverend Sisters of the staff.

His Lordship has made urgent request to be reimbursed towards the cost of the erection of the building, to the amount of $10,000.00. Funds to provide for the payment of this amount are available in our Estimates for the current fiscal year.

Dear Phil:

May I remind you of requests for beds intended for our different schools. As the school year is at hand and in the case of Fort Vermillion navigation will soon come to an end I take the liberty of writing again in the matter. Kindly attend to the matter. I would suggest you take Parkhill Bedding Co. of Edmonton (the Company is on the privileged list at least in Winnipeg where are the Headquarters) in order to have uniformity and secure repairs when necessary. Almost all our beds are from that firm.

The Fort Vermilion School needs 6 Fire Extinguishers of 2½ gallons Each (Loose Stopple Type). We have built an addition 24'x 30', three stories high, and as there were not enough fire extinguishers beforehand I would appreciate your sending the above.

Here in Grouard, we have built a school 40'x50' two stories high (four class rooms) and full concrete basement. We have built a three story addition to the girls house, 24'x28' with bakery and dairy in the basement and a 100'x36' cow stable. We need fire extinguishers for all these additions as also for the laundry which is now being installed (20'x40') in the basement of the boys' house. Could you kindly attend to the matter and oblige me thereby.

Kindly send us here time sheets (quite a number as I also need some for Joussard school) and a good number to Wabasca R.C. School (DESMARAIS P.O.).

The June quarter grants did not show as yet and whilst you are at it could you think of the advances on the September one.

Excuse my begging ways and present best regards to Mrs. Phelan and family.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Bishop of Grouard.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Water Supply for Ft. Vermilion Indian Residential School.

As instructed in your memorandum of January 20th last, arrangements were made for an inspection of the water supply at the above School, and report received is attached in duplicate.

The present methods of obtaining water at this School are apparently most primitive. Also, there is no interior plumbing in the building and toilets are dry and outside. The possibility of improvement in the future, in the way of interior sanitary plumbing, has therefore to be kept in mind when considering action in connection with the water supply.

From his investigations our Engineer's opinion is that water must be obtained either from wells or from the Peace River. He favours, as the most suitable and economical solution, endeavouring to get water from wells in close proximity to the buildings.

We therefore recommend the work estimated at $1,650.00 by our Engineer, and detailed on page 2 of his report. This covers the digging of a well, construction near well of a pumphouse to house a 3,000 gallon tank and pump, and the laying of a capacity pipe line from pumphouse to two 600 gallon tanks in the basement of convent as well as two new 600 gallon tank to be installed in the basement of the boys' dormitory.

The water will then be distributed through the buildings by hand as has been done in the past, or if the Indian Affairs Department wish to stand on power at interior plumbing two shallow well electric pumps at $125.00 each might be purchased for interior distribution of water which would increase the total estimate to $1,900.00 as given on page 3 of our Engineer's report. The power available is a 9 H.P. engine with a Lister, 110 volt, D.C. generator.

In the above estimate, expenditures for labour are based on prevailing rates in the district as referred to by our Engineer in the second last paragraph of his report.

Respectfully submitted,

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

REPORT on Water Supply Situation at
Fort Vermillion Mission, Alta.
February 9th, 1939.

The mission buildings are situated on the right bank of the Peace River and on a flat bench about six or seven feet above the usual high-water mark. During the spring of 1934 an ice-jam in the river caused the flow to back up and flood this bench to a depth of from one to two feet of water.

Behind the mission buildings a range of low hills parallels the river bank with the base of the hills being about 1500 feet back from the river bank. Along the base of the hills runs an old beaver channel which would be about three feet lower than the ground upon which the mission buildings are sited. This depression is now thickly wooded with poplar and spruce trees and is wet during the spring and early summer. This depression acts as a collecting basin for the spring run-off from the hills and also for water coming from weak springs and seepages along the base of the hill.

The mission buildings have no plumbing or baths and the toilets are all dry and outside. The water, which to a person used to modern city water supply facilities is at present used most sparingly, is obtained from two wells and collected rainwater, while the drinking water is obtained by melting ice obtained from the Peace River. One well is situated near the barn and supplies the stock. This well is 25 feet deep with a 5 foot bottom and has about 4 feet of water standing in it and a fairly strong flow. The other well is inside the kitchen of the convent and is 23 feet deep, 5 x 5 foot bottom, and has about 3'-6" of water in it, but not a strong flow. This well water is fairly hard for washing and laundry purposes and the Sisters prefer to use rainwater or water hauled from the river for these purposes.

I was informed by the mission authorities that seepages of water occur along the river bank in the vicinity of the mission. These did not show at the time of my inspection, February 9th. This fact, combined with that of the present wells,
leads me to believe that sufficient water for the mission could be found in a well or wells, if proper water storage facilities are provided. At present there are two 600-gallon tanks in the basement of the convent used for storing rainwater collected from the roof.

The mission principal, Rev. Father Guernereur, was hopeful that some means could be found to pipe water to the mission from the springs and seepages along the base of the hills behind the mission. I was taken to the site of the strongest spring, a distance of over 2000 feet from the convent building, and found it to be absolutely dry with no flow on the 9th February, 1939. There was an area of a few square yards of ice around the site but no sign of any flow of water. In view of the absence of water on that date, I do not think it worth while to give the proposition of piping water from these springs and seepages any further consideration; which means that any additional supply of water for the mission must be obtained from wells or the Peace River the most suitable and economical solution being that of getting it from wells in close proximity to the buildings.

In drawing up any plans for a water supply system, probable early developments and improvements in facilities should be taken into consideration. At present the water facilities are not very advanced except the absence of outside dry toilets, no inside plumbing whatever and no fire protection. I believe that when funds are available the Indian Affairs Branch would like to install inside plumbing with baths, toilets and septic tanks, and provide fire hydrants, and I was given to understand that it is probable a hospital will be built at this mission in the near future. With this in mind, I beg to make the following recommendations for providing a sufficient supply of water. These recommendations will cover only digging a well, providing increased storage facilities and taking the water from the well to the storage tanks. They will not cover the cost of distributing the water throughout the interior of the buildings.

I would suggest that first of all a well be found containing a suitable quantity of water. I suggested a site about 200 feet behind the convent where it is believed a well 23 to 25 feet deep will be sufficient. If this is made with a 6 x 6 foot bottom, a flow of from 1200 to 1500 gallons a day will probably be found. If this flow, or better, is found on this site, an electric deep well pump should be installed and a lumber tank to hold 3000 gallons of water built over the well, both pump and tank to be housed in a warmly built sunhouse with a small heater. The water can then flow by gravity through 1-1/8" mains buried at least 7 feet underground to the present storage tanks in the basement of the convent and to a new 600-gallon tank which should be installed in the...
basement of the boys' dormitory. The water can then be distributed from the basements throughout the buildings by automatic shallow well type electric pumps.

The purpose of the 3000-gallon storage tank is to provide a reservoir where a reserve supply of water may be built up for washdays and for fire protection purposes. The well should be sited so as to minimize the possibility of contamination from surface water. Consequently, it should be well away from the barns and dry privies and away from the disposal field of any probable septic tank system.

ESTIMATE OF COST

Digging and cribbing well $120.00
Constructing 3000-gal. storage tank (lumber), including materials $100.00
Constructing pumphouse (frame construction), including materials $450.00
450 lineal feet 1-1/2" galvanized iron pipe with fittings, delivered to Pt. Vermilion $130.00
One, deep well type electric pump, installed with 2" casing $200.00
Two, shallow well electric pumps @ 125.00 $250.00
Excavating trench for pipe and backfilling $275.00
Laying pipe $25.00
One, 600-gal. galvanized iron water tank (not pressure tank) $200.00
Contingencies and Engineering expenses $180.00

$2,900.00

Should this project be approved, I would recommend that the work be done by the local mission authorities under the Indian Affairs Branch. The prevailing rates for labour paid by the mission are little more than half those of the western Fair Wage Scale set by the Dept. of Labour and for our Branch to go in there and pay the higher rates of pay would make things decidedly awkward for the local authorities. Consequently, I believe that best interests of the department will be served if the Engineering Service remains in an advisory capacity only.

The work can be undertaken at any season of the year, although winter work would put the cost of labour up. Probably, the best time to do this work would be the late summer time or fall of the year.

C.K. Lebapelin
Assistant Engineer.
March 10, 1939

Re: Water supply for Indian schools at Grouard, Fort Vermilion, Sturgeon Lake and Joussard.

We have practically no information about the ground water occurrences near the above mentioned schools, but judging from the geology it seems advisable to limit the depth of drilling in some cases.

The chances of getting a water supply near the Sturgeon Lake School are probably good. The district is underlain by the Wapiti formation which contains several sand horizons that carry a good water supply in the Peace River district. I cannot tell to what depth you will have to drill here but it should be no deeper than the top of the black shale which underlies the Wapiti formation.

The chances are probably poor of getting a supply of good water from the bedrock of all the other schools and drilling should be confined to the surface deposits. The bedrock in these places is a black or dark grey shale.

It is impossible to tell exactly where you should drill, without having seen the ground. Usually in searching for water in the surface deposits, gravel ridges and stream valleys are good places to prospect.

We will be very glad to co-operate with you in any way we can, and if you wish to consult us please do so at any time.

If you drill please let us know what results you get in order that we may have the information on file.

(Sgd.) R.T.D. Wickenden.

Instructions for doing necessary work at Fort Vermilion:

(1) Excavate a trench 7 foot deep from the well to the corner of the girls' dormitory and from thence to Boys' dormitory. The 720 gallon pressure tank should be installed horizontally under the boys' dormitory. Excavate a trench 7 foot deep from the corner of the girls' dormitory to a convenient point for taking water into the kitchen.

Excavate a place for the pressure tank in the basement of the boys' dormitory. Excavate a trench from the well to the water's edge to depth shown on accompanying plan and dynamite a trench from the water's edge to a point where the water will be about 5 to 7 feet deep in winter, according to instructions for doing this kind of work that will be sent you by the C.I.L.

(2) As soon as approval of location is received from the Provincial Government dig and crib well 6' x 6' inside on the site shown on the plan and staked on the ground. Crib with 2" plank with 4"x4" or 2"x6" corner pieces. This well should be dug about 50' deep if possible below level of road or to 10' below the level of the river so that the well will be in water bearing strata which will likely be encountered at a depth of from 20 to 25 feet will likely be hard surface water and should be prevented from entering the well if possible by a clay coating outside the cribbing at the point where it enters. The aim in digging this well is two-fold; (1) to endeavour to get a flow of soft water from the river and to form a reservoir for storing or clarifying water that could be pumped into it from the river.

(3) As soon as pipe arrives, lay it in the trench and cover with straw and then earth. Be sure all the branch fittings or offtakes have been placed where desired or shown on the plan before covering pipe.

Dear Sir,

I was just starting to write you in connection with the credit allotted for the water system at Fort Vermilion Indian School when your letter reached me this morning.

According to the estimates made by the Engineers, the expense there will amount to $1,650.00. Having received but $500.00, the Principal complaints of shortage of money to have the work properly done and the material paid. It would surely relieve the Father if the balance of the money allotted for the installation of the water was forwarded to him without delay. I understand that you await a request to do so. Please forward money, I mean the balance, as soon as possible.

I have not received yet any details as to the cost of the work. I hope it will not run over the estimates. We should know before long.

Here, at Grouard, it is not easy to find suitable water. Water was encountered at 330 feet, rather soft water, but it was so dirty that it was out of question to use such water. We have to go deeper. By the rest, the laying of the pipes is over. If we could get water, the installation would be completed in a few days.

Thanking you for the interest you pay to our problems,

I remain,

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

Re: Grouard Indian Residential School
Joussard Indian Residential School
Vernillion Indian Residential School
Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School

This week Right Reverend U. Langlois, O.M.I., Bishop of Grouard, visited this Branch and discussed with us the work that is in progress in connection with the water supply system at each of the above-mentioned schools.

As you have previously been informed funds were provided in the current year's appropriation for the improvements suggested by your engineers. However, it appears from the information received from Bishop Langlois that the work has not yet been completed.

No provision is being made in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1940-41 for money required in connection with the water systems at these schools and moreover the principal of each of the schools is anxious to secure a considerable amount of new equipment if funds available in the current year's appropriation are not being used in connection with the water systems.

The season is advancing and I am extremely anxious to know at the earliest possible date what progress has been made at each of the four schools mentioned above, also when the water systems at these schools will be completed.
I understand from the information contained in memoranda that you have submitted in connection with the above that all the materials required have been purchased.

I trust that you will find it possible to let me have, at the earliest possible date, a complete statement regarding the situation at each of these schools.

Director.

Grouard, Alta., Nov. 24, 1939.

"Dear Mr. Schmidt:

Let me thank you for the attention given to the Watchman's Clock for Fort Vermilion.

I fully agree that the appropriation for Fort Vermilion for the year will be used entirely for the water system. Dear Mr. Hoey,

Answering yours of the 30th of April last re: Requisition of Tools and of some Sport Goods for our Fort Vermilion Residential School, I beg to state that I deem it would be a bad policy to refuse equipment if we want to train children in most usual work. The inability of most Indians due to unpreparedness to provide for themselves has been deplored since too long. The Department is anxious to remediate to the situation by having the young generation taught in the most usual trades. The Principals of our Schools take a keen interest in the matter. I think it would be unfair to them to refuse the equipment absolutely needed to obtain results.

Should I understand that this expense will be charged against the appropriation allotted to our Schools for repairs and equipment for the year 1940-41? I hope not. Should not at least the tools for the workshop and the garden be paid by the Department from another source? These tools come for Indian Schools in the school material as manual Training as a part of the course the children receive. If you can't do so, I mean avoid to charge these tools against the coming allotment for our Schools, please let me know.

As to the Gymnasium Equipment, I would be pleased to hear that the Department will take care of it too. If it is found impossible, please postpone filling the requisition. I will see what we can do to remediate the present situation.

Your letter brings me bad news. The appropriation for repairs and equipment in our schools is reduced to $7,050.00. It is not much for five schools.
I hope that this curtailment will not be followed by a reduction of the grants re: pupilage. If the price of life commodities keeps on going up, the situation will become serious if not critical before long. We are doing our best to get revenue from farm and garden, but there is no remedy to draught. It looks better this spring. Sufficient moisture for the season. We need warm weather.

I appreciate that you will submit to me any request presented by any of our schools. It will help keeping the money for most necessary expenditure.

While in Ottawa, I applied to Mr. Phelan for two sewing machines (not Tailor's) for Wabasca. It does not seem that they have been shipped at date. As there is a lot of tailor's work to be done in summer time, I would appreciate these two machines being shipped as soon as possible. Address: R.C. Indian Residential School, Wabasca, via Slave Lake, Alta.

Let me profit by this opportunity to thank you for the interest you have paid to the refund of monies advanced for the water system. I was surely pleased to hear that Sturgeon Lake School had received the $500.00 recommended by the Engineers.

May I point out that there should be a balance of $111.60 coming for Fort Vermilion. I presume this will not delay.

In February, I presented a bill for transportation of children at our Grouard School. Not having heard of since, I wonder if I can expect refund. May I put the same question for J.H. Ashdown Hardware Co.'s bill covering Watchman Clock for Fort Vermilion. Vouchers were attached.

Thanking you once more, I remain,

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Yours truly,

F.S. Lajoie, O.M.I.
Grouard, Alta.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Excuse if I have delayed so long acknowledging receipt of yours of May 28th. Being alone at Grouard, I am called out of Town quite often.

I am surely pleased to know that it has been possible to raise credit for Repairs and Improvements and for Purchase of New Equipment to $9,800.00. It is less than last year, but yet better than announced previously. We surely need this to face the situation. The reduction on per capita grant will reflect heavily on our finances. We do our best to cut expenses.

I take notice of what you say about the purchasing of two sewing machines for Wabasca and of tools for Fort Vermillion as well as of the charging of $50.00 for the Watchman's Clock for this school. For this item, let me point out that it has been paid and vouchers forwarded. May I expect refund before long.

As to the balance I was expecting as refund for the expenses incurred for the Water System at Fort Vermillion, it is not easy for me to give full details as I have not in hands copy of all the vouchers sent by Rev. F. Huguerre. Neither do I get a detailed report of the items covered by Department's cheque 33812, $266.60. According to F. Huguerre's statement, it has been expended $2,378.85. If I had details of the amount of $226.60 referred to above, it could be possible for me to trace this balance.

As soon as the Bishop will be back, we will decide on the use of the credit and let you know.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Please find enclosed report of wages paid at our Fort Vermilion Indian Residential School for the completion of the Water System.

Last year, it had been impossible to finish the work due to cold weather in fall as well as to the raising of the water in the river. They have profited by the nice weather this fall to complete the work.

They have been fortunate enough to get an abundant supply of fairly soft water. It is a big improvement on what they had in the past. Let us hope that the water problem is solved at the Fort Vermilion Indian School for many years if not forever.

Grouard, Alta., August 21st, 1941.

Mr. R.A. Hoey, Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Parliament Buildings,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I am just notified by Rev. Father Huguerre, Principal at the Indian School at Fort Vermillion, that the roof of flour-mill has to be renewed this year. The heavy rains of this summer have disclosed that the old roof is not safe especially on a flour-mill.

As the last scheduled trip for Fort Vermillion will leave Peace River in the last week of September, I take the liberty of requesting the authorization of ordering myself the material needed. Besides, it is not easy to give by letter the precise specifications of the material needed. We want a galvanized iron roof, undulated. According to the traveller of The Western Steel Products who called on me this morning, the material will cost $150.00 around.

You are surely aware that it is not easy to get prompt delivery of material just now. It is why I would appreciate an answer within a short future. We can't take any chance on the flour and we have just a month or so to have the material shipped this fall. This is going by Air Mail.

Thanking you in advance for the attention you will give to this matter, I remain, Dear Mr. Hoey,

Yours truly,

F. S. LaJoie, O.M.I.,

Grouard, Alta.

April 26th 1945

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Enclosed herewith application to the Wartime Prices
and Trade Board to purchase new farm equipment for the Fort
Vermilion Indian Residential School and Hospital. Specific
information regarding the farm machinery that is required and
reasons why this equipment is urgently needed are given on the
application form.

Now, I quite understand that it is impossible to
obtain this equipment for shipment this Spring, but it would be
satisfactory if the equipment could be forwarded to Fort Vermilion
during the navigation period, that is, from June to August
inclusively, so the equipment could reach Fort Vermilion this year,
so it could be available for use next Spring. If the equipment
did not reach Fort Vermilion this year, this would mean that it could
be used before the Spring of 1947.

As explained to you in my letter of March 26th,
the Fort Vermilion Residential School is purchasing this equipment
from their own funds and would therefore reimburse the Department
the cost of this farm machinery.

I trust that the purchasing Agent of the Department
will do all he possibly can to secure this equipment and forward
same this Summer. Spring is very late here this year and ice is
still very solid on the Peace River although navigation usually
opens at the end of April. It usually closes on September 20th;
this explains why the order should reach Peace River no later than
the end of August to make sure that delivery can be made in time.

There you have in a short story how merchandise is
delivered to the Fort Vermilion Residential School; it is only
from May to September that supplies can be shipped to Fort Vermilion;
They can not shop all year round, as you or I can do so.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

September 19, 1944.

AIR MAIL

Reverend Sir:

The Department has been endeavouring to secure a Beatty Model 6 A Electric Washer for the Vermilion School. Owing to present conditions it will not be possible to secure this for several months and that will mean that the washer would not go forward to you this fall. In order that purchase may be made from funds available at the present time we intend to order the washer and will ship it to the Bishop's residence at McLellan, where it can remain for the winter and go forward to Vermilion in the spring. Before finally placing the order we desire to know if the washer should be fitted with a 32 volt or 115 volt direct current motor. Please let me have this information by air mail.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Principal,

Ottawa September 13, 1944.

Memorandum

Dr. H.W. McGill

With reference to your requisition of the 31st ultimo, for one Beatty Model 6A electric washer for the Vermilion Indian Residential School, I may say that the results of tenders indicate that there is no possibility of supplying this washer before the close of navigation.

The manufacturers state that there are no motors available for many months, and the Edmonton Branch have advised that they cannot make any definite commitment as to delivery but, basing it on their experience during the past year, it will be at least three months. They also ask whether the washer should be fitted with a 32 volt or 115 volt direct current motor. The price placed on the washer f.o.b. cars Edmonton, is $245.00.

In view of the above will you kindly advise regarding the placing of this order.

Departmental Purchasing Agent.

WMV/HC

Dear Mr. Neary:

In reply to your letter of the 7th instant, I beg to submit the following requisition for each of the residential schools in the Grouard Diocese.

Re: Fort Vermilion

Father Rainville reported again and again this year that a new set of batteries was urgently required for his lighting plant. He explained that the set that he has on hand is over ten years old and the batteries are worn out. If you could arrange to secure a new set type W 21 Globelite Batteries 21 plate per cell, 56 cells for 110 volts, you would greatly relieve him. Navigation closes on the Peace River about October 1st. These batteries would therefore have to reach Peace River by then and ordered immediately. I understand that Bruce-Robinson Electric Co., Edmonton, have these batteries on hand. It would expedite matters if they were ordered from them.

At present, Father Rainville is building a horse and cow barn 124 x 36 for which the Department has defrayed the cost of equipment and corrugated aluminum for the roof. If an additional sum of $300.00 was available to pay part of the lumber and labour, I feel assured that this amount would lessen the burden of the Principal who is to be commended for the fine building that he has undertaken which will be to the credit of the Department.

Re: Grouard

When in Ottawa last January, I informed the Department that the lighting plant was destroyed by fire at Grouard on December 31st, 1947. As the school was without light and power and the matter of replacing this plant was urgent, I was asked to take the necessary steps to buy a new engine, generator and batteries upon my arrival at Edmonton. This plant was bought and is now installed.

It was explained to me that there was at that time a credit balance of some $1700. in favour of the residential schools in the Grouard Diocese from the amount provided in the estimate for 1947-48, and it was agreed that this amount would be applied to cover part of the cost of a new lighting plant for Grouard Residential School and that the balance would be paid from the estimates for 1948-49. On March 24th, 1948, I forwarded to the Department receipted invoices from Bruce Robinson Electric Limited, Edmonton, in the amount of $4687.00 for this purchase but the account has not been paid as yet. I would
Mr. Neary:

appreciate this amount being reimbursed. Should you not have received the invoices, kindly let me know and I shall have additional copies made and forwarded to you.

Re: Joussard

The amount of $1500.00 is required for general repairs at Joussard. Years ago buildings were constructed on wooden blocks and cement foundations should be made under these buildings in order to prevent their deterioration. If the Department is prepared to pay labour for the amount of $1500.00, the school will defray the cost of lumber, cement, nails and the balance of the labour required.

Re: Sturgeon Lake

At Sturgeon Lake, a new cow and horse barn is required to replace the old dilapidated log one which threatens to cave in. It is the intention of the Principal to build this new barn in 1949. If $2000.00 were available immediately from the 1948-49 appropriation, the lumber could be bought this fall so that construction of the building may begin early in the spring of 1949, and a further amount made available from the estimates of 1948-49 to carry out the project.

Re: Wabasca

Father Guimont called at the Bishop's House last night and explained that the floor of some of the rooms were in very bad condition and worn out, and required to be replaced. I believe that the sum of $1500.00 would cover the cost of replacing these floors and covering them with linoleum. I shall get in touch with the Principal and ask him to let me know the amount of flooring and the number of yards of linoleum required for the job, and shall give you this information as soon as it is available. If you will arrange to have the sum of $1500.00 available for these repairs, I believe that it would cover this expenditure. I understand that the flooring could be obtained locally at Wabasca but the linoleum would have to be secured by your purchasing branch.

I believe, Mr. Neary, that the above requisitions are legitimate and trust that you will give them your very careful consideration.

Yours very truly,

Rev. L. Beuglet, O.M.I.

Naturally, we expect the Principal of the school at which an allowance for a night watchman has been authorized to forward a Voucher regularly. If he does not do so, it is presumed that he is not engaging a night watchman.

If you employed a night watchman for the month of April, 1948, and also for the months of October, November, December, 1948, and January and February, 1949, you may forward a Voucher through the office of Superintendent Lapp for six months at $60.00 per month. The Voucher should read:

"Allowance towards the salary of night watchman for the months of April, October, November, December, 1948, and January and February, 1949, six months at $60.00 per month - $360.00."

certify your Voucher and forward it to the Department for payment when he receives it from you.

Please give the matter your immediate attention, as our fiscal year closes at the end of this month.

Yours sincerely,

a resident of Hay Lake. He was a patient in the

time he was at Fort Vermilion. We found it would be
cheaper to have the animals cared for by the R.C.

farmers.

given in paragraph two, regarding having them

to this case as well.

Re: Sports Equipment - Fort Vermilion Indian Residential School

Attached hereto is a self-explanatory letter from Father G. Tetreault of the Fort Vermilion Indian Residential School.

I understand from Father Tetreault that this school got a grant of $4,200.00. They have just received a new lighting plant and paint for the school. Any remaining funds from this grant will be used for some very essential and much needed kitchen equipment.

There is no question that the school here has practically no recreational equipment. If there is a special fund available for such items as sports equipment, anything you can do for us in this matter will be appreciated very much. I feel that the request made by Father Tetreault is very just.

S. C. Knapp,
Superintendent.
Fort Vermilion Indian Residential School,
FORT VERMILION, Alberta,
November 22nd, 1949.

Mr. S. C. Knapp, Superintendent,
Fort Vermilion Indian Agency,
FORT VERMILION, Alta.

Dear Mr. Knapp:

I come today to see if you could not interest or persuade your Department to accord immediately a special grant for the purchase of skates for the Indian Pupils attending our school. It seems to me that sporting activities are essential for the good health and character formation of the children; and as regards sporting equipment I believe sincerely that our school has been much less favored than numerous Indian Schools which I know of in the Province which have received substantial grants for sporting equipment and even for the erection of gymnasiums and halls.

As you no doubt remarked, I have begun a skating rink in the boys' yard this winter -- the first time a constructed rink has been undertaken in this school. However, and here is the hook, I have but twelve pairs of skates belonging to the Indian Pupils and you must admit that these are not very numerous for our enrolment. Moreover in view of our precarious financial situation at the moment I do not find the additional expense of purchasing a sufficient number of skates justifiable (a very good thing, but not essential) when the school as a whole is short of so many absolutely necessary things.

I ask for very little....some ten or twelve additional pairs of skates will prove satisfactory for this winter. The children can amuse themselves and learn how to skate well this winter -- next winter will be soon enough to think of hockey equipment and organized games.

Hoping you will find my request reasonable and do your utmost to have it accepted by your Department, I remain,

Very sincerely yours,
Fort Vermilion Indian Residential School,
Per: (Signed)'G. Tetreault, O.M.I.'
Rev. G. Tetreault, O.M.I., Bursar.

Ottawa, January 21, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of the December quarter return of the Vermilion (St. Henry) Indian Residential School, together with applications and certificates of health for the admission of John Bulldog and Francis Kipling. The admission of these two boys is approved. Please advise the Principal accordingly.

You should instruct the Principal that, in future, when preparing his quarterly returns, he should fill in all the columns of the return, opposite the name of each pupil. It is particularly requested that he fill in the columns under the heading "Class of study". All sheets of the return should be added and the totals carried forward and shown on the last sheet of the return.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

N. P. L'Heureux, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Driftpile, Alta.
Driftpile, Alberta,
January 27th, 1937.

Sir,

The Principal of St Henry's Residential School at Fort Vermillion reports that one pupil, Madeleine Baasa, is now over age. (No. 0154.)

As she is in poor health and has no relatives to go to upon leaving school, the principal requests your permission to keep her in school for another year.

Yours faithfully,

N. P. L'Heureux,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA.
Ottawa, February 2, 1937.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 27th ultimo, you may inform the Principal of the Vermilion Indian Residential School that the Department approves Madeleine Baasa, No. 0154, remaining in the school for another year.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

The Acting Principal of the St Henry's Indian Residential School, Fort Vermilion, applies as per letter herewith for the admission as grant earning pupils, of the following halfbreed children:

LAURENT MORVAN, aged 3, the son of a halfbreed father and of a Treaty Indian mother now dead. This child has been adopted by Headman Walter Jean Courtoiselle, No. 31 Little Red River Band;

ELISE HAMELIN, aged 14
VICTOR HAMELIN, aged 10
HENRY HAMELIN, aged 9

the children of Samuel Hamelin, a Halfbreed residing with his family at Little Red River, where there are no day schools under provincial or religious auspices.

Re Laurent Morvan. This child not being of school age I cannot, as much as I appreciate to see him in school, recommend the full grant. If the Department will make a small allowance to the Mission to help defray his maintenance this I think would be satisfactory to the Principal.

Re Elise, Victor and Henry Hamelin, halfbreeds from a family we may well consider destitute, living the Indian mode of life, I recommend their admission as grant earning pupils.

Ottawa, December 16, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of November 23rd with reference to the request that you have received for the admission of certain children to the Vermilion Indian Residential School.

With regard to Laurent Morvan, it is noted that he has been adopted by Headman Walter Jean Courtoeille. You did not state the date of his adoption and, as the boy is only three years of age, it would appear that the adoption must have taken place recently and possibly for the purpose of having the boy placed in an Indian Residential school. In view of his age, we are not prepared to approve his admission at the present time. However, if Courtoeille keeps the boy until he reaches the regular age for admission, the Department will be prepared to favorably consider placing him in a residential school at that time.

From the information contained in your letter, we are not prepared to approve the admission of Elise, Victor and Henry Hamelin as grant earning pupils to the Indian residential school. You should so inform the Principal.

It is considered that this school should have no difficulty in obtaining sufficient treaty Indian children to bring their enrolment to the number for which grant is provided.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

N.P. L'Heureux, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Rev. F. S. Lajoie, O.M.I.,
Administrator,
Diocese of Grouard,
Grouard, Alta.
The Royal Canadian Mounted Police are being informed that no further action toward returning children to the Vermilion School may be taken at the present time.

The statement of the Police that the parents are dissatisfied with the compulsion being used in keeping the boys in school until 16 years of age raises a question which has been discussed for some time, especially with the Right Reverend G. Breynat, O.M.I., in regard to the schools in the Northwest Territories. As the living conditions of the Little Red River Band of Indians are practically the same as those in the Northwest Territories it is felt that the same regulations should apply to them as apply to the Indians in the Northwest Territories. These are as follows:

1. The age limit for discharge of boys to be 14 years and girls 16 years.

2. Boys, upon reaching 12 years of age, if in good physical condition, may be granted leave of absence each year for the period during the hunting and trapping season and thereafter returned to school. This arrangement to be continued in their case until they reach the full age of 14 years, when they are to be discharged.

3. Girls, in special cases, if considered in their interests, may be permitted, upon request of the Principal of the School and the local Agent, or other departmental representative, to remain until they reach the age of 18 years. The reasons, in such cases, should be forwarded to the Department concerned and permission obtained for girls to remain a further period after reaching the age of 16 years, but not beyond the age of 18 years.

4. In the case of orphan and destitute children, Principals of schools and local departmental representatives should arrange to have them placed, upon their discharge, with families who will properly care for them and provide for their future welfare and also arrange, in the case of boys 12 to 14 years of age, to be placed with a family in order that they can acquire a knowledge of hunting and trapping.
It may be possible that the above conditions should also apply to other children attending the Vermilion Residential School or to the Indian Residential Schools in the Diocese of Grouard.

I feel certain that you will realize the reasonableness of these regulations and will co-operate with the Department in putting them into effect. A copy of this letter is being sent to the Principal of the Vermilion Residential School.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

Answering yours of the 8th inst., I have to state that I will do my best to cooperate with the Department for the welfare of Indian children. As your letter touches many important problems, my intention is to have it carefully studied by the Board of Administration of the Vicariate of Grouard. The Residential Indian School of Fort Vermilion being especially concerned, I am requesting the observations the Principal may have to make.

Let me express you my first impression. While admitting the necessity of preparing the Indian boys to their future life, bush life as you say, I can't refrain from making a remark: What would be the use of training youngsters to trapping and fishing if there is to be no more fur or fish. Surely, you have been told that the situation for the Indians is becoming alarming. One has to see to understand what it means. The fact is this: wild life has nearly disappeared in the North due to the fact that white people have been allowed to enter the wilderness. White trappers and fishermen, having no lively interest in the preservation of fur, game or fish kill and catch as much as they can. They use the airplane to invade the remotest sanctuaries where wild life is reproduced. They annihilate rats' and beavers' families; they empty lakes and rivers from any valuable fish and they go further when there is nothing left in their first fields of operation. The natives have to stay and make a living in the country.

There is a remedy, drastic but the only one effective. It would be to close the North Country to White trappers and fishermen. The small loss of revenue produced by the sale of licenses to white people would be largely compensated not only by the saving of relief but especially by keeping the Indians busy. Laziness is bad for white people; it is mortal for Indians.

The problem is serious enough that every man in responsibility should stick at and bring his share to find an adequate settlement. It is useless to work against nature. The Indians of the North are bush Indians as you say; let the bush be habitable for them and they will make a living.

The reports on trapping are discouraging. No fur at all; hardly a few moose. What will happen next summer? Most of the families will not have a nickel to buy clothes and food. And it will be worse in the coming years unless drastic measures are adopted to protect and reconstitute the source of wild life. This can be performed by reserving trapping and fishing to Indians.

Excuse me, Sir, if I have kept you so long on our main problem here.

Yours very truly,

(sgd.) F. S. Lajoie, O.M.I.,
Administrator,
Diocese of Grouard, Alta.

Dear Sir:

I have received a copy of the letter concerning the Indians of Little Red River and their dissatisfaction at being compelled to send their children to the school at Fort Vermilion. This letter, File No. 431-13-10, was addressed to Rev. F.S. Lajoie, Administrator of Grouard, also the Regulations to be followed in future regarding the age limit for the discharge of the pupils of this school, for all of which I wish to thank you.

We have always had considerable difficulty with the school attendance in this district, due to the fact that there is no resident Agent near to the school. Mr. L'Heureux, our Agent resides some 400 miles from here, and partly too, because the school is so far from some of the Reserves from which our pupils come.

These Reserves are the Little Red River, 60 miles, and the Tall Cree Reserve 45 miles, for the Crees. The Slaves are not as yet constituted into reserves. They are at Hay River, 90 miles, and at Hay Lakes, 125 miles. The pupils from this district that we have are mostly orphan or destitute children. The two Beaver Reserves of Eleske, 24 miles, and Boyer River, 12 miles, present little difficulty as far as distance is concerned, the point to be gained with them is to have all the pupils of school age brought to school for the opening of classes, September 1st. The Beavers can and usually do bring in the children, but never for the first day.

It is the more distant pupils of Tall Cree and Red River who give us most trouble. It was for this reason that we appealed for assistance to Constable Grayson this year. Would it not be possible for some arrangement to be made, as he suggested in this report, through Mr. L'Heureux, at Treaty time, that the Indian Department do something about this matter? At Grouard and at Joussard the pupils are brought to the school by their parents, or if difficulty arises, by the Agent, or some one, authorized by him, I believe. Could not some such arrangement be made for us? If so, it will be greatly appreciated, and will do much to eliminate a good deal of the trouble we have each year in September.
It is true that the Red River Indians are not satisfied with the present arrangement of affairs. They say it is because the school is so far from them and they cannot see their children from September until June. And I believe too, they do not like to be urged too much to put the children in school. But since the boys are to be discharged at 14 years hereafter, that should encourage them to send in the younger children. That is the difficulty to get in the children at 7 years.

These Indians of Red River and the Slaves of the Hay Lakes and Hay River district have repeatedly asked at Treaty time that the Agent and the priest in charge speak to the proper authorities concerned in their favour, about having a school in or near their reserves, then assuring us that they would send in their children willing, as they would then be able to visit them from time to time, but they find the school at Fort Vermilion too far away from their homes. This is a very legitimate proposition, and worthy of consideration by the civil and religious authorities.

I will greatly appreciate any assistance you may be able to give us in these matters.

Truly yours,

Parliament Buildings,

Dear Sir,

I am requested to transmit to the Department a bill covering expenses incurred at Fort Vermilion for transportation of the children in July and in September. I don't delay the forwarding of this bill with the reports on repair work as I foresee to be in great need of money by the end of this month. The coming of the winter is imposing heavy buying.

The dry weather keeps on. No serious rain since a year. Besides the failure of the crop, we are facing fire hazard. Unless it rains this fall, we will have to spend quite a sum cleaning around here. Expense and anxiety.

Believe me, Dear Sir,

Yours truly,

F. S. LaJe, O.M.I.,
Grouard, Alta.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 12th ultimo enclosing applications and certificates of health for the admission of Victor and Henry Hamelin, Frederick Hamelin and Alice and Daniel Hodgson to the Vermilion Indian Residential School.

From the information contained in your letter the Department does not consider that these children are eligible for admission and grant earning pupils to an Indian Residential School. Consequently it will not be possible to allow per capita grant for them. In this case also I would again direct your attention to the ruling contained in official letter of December 10, 1937, copy of which is enclosed. What has been said regarding applications for admission of halfbreeds to the Sturgeon Lake School applies also in the case of the Vermilion and other Residential Schools in your Agency. The Department trusts that the Principals will carefully review circular letter of December 10, 1937, and confine their recruiting efforts to treaty Indian children.

Reverend Sir:

I received your letter of the 4th ultimo enclosing account covering the cost of transportation of children to and from the Fort Vermilion Residential School during the past summer.

The account amounted to $169.00 but as the amount available for travelling expenses is very limited and as no special provision was made for the Vermilion Residential School due to the fact that you did not apply to the Department for authority to incur such expenses it was only found possible to allow an amount of $100.00, a cheque for which amount is going forward to the Principal of the Vermilion Residential School.

I note that the account included charges of $57.00 for transporting children from the school to Red River. Would it not have been possible to have the parents come for the children?
