Date OCTOBER 4th., 1939

Re: Rev. Father HUGERRE, Fort Vermilion, Alta.,
Compl. of TRUANT INDIAN CHILDREN.

Headquarters

1. The above named came to this office at noon of the 2-10-39, to notify that the following twenty Indian children had been missing from the St. Henry Mission School since 9 AM of that morning: Ambrose TALL CREE, Gabriel MINIE, and Ernest AUGER. These boys, aged 12, 11, and 9 years, respectively, had failed to answer the Breakfast Roll-Call and had last been seen in the school yard just prior to 9 AM. TALL CREE and MINIE both come from the Tall Cree Reserve, 60 miles south of this point, and where their parents are residing. The AUGER boy's home is near Little Red River, which is 65 miles east of Fort Vermilion, on the Peace River. There was no immediate information as to where these boys may have gone.

Sub-Division

2. Investigation disclosed that the missing lads very probably had run away from School and would attempt to reach their homes. Since they are very young it was urgent that they be located as soon as possible, due to the danger of their becoming lost, or being drowned in the River. The road to the Tall Cree reserve is a bush trail for about 60 miles and then the road reaches the Tall Cree Prairie. This is a very isolated district, the road is seldom travelled and no one lives on or near it. At 5 PM of the same day I was hired locally, and I sent S/Gst. Bourassa to investigate along this trail to make an effort to locate any of these lads travelling on foot. He was instructed to make every effort to locate tracks and should any be found follow and apprehend and return the boys.

P.C.R.

Pt. Ver. First.

3. Several years ago, several Truant boys attempted to escape from the school by stealing a canoe and floating down river to Little Red River. After a careful check of all settlements for any stolen canoe or boat, and also searched the surrounding district for these boys. Since S/Gst. Bourassa did not return late PM, I presumed that he had found signs along the Tall Cree Reserve road and was following. He returned the following day with TALL CREE, MINIE and AUGER, that he had overtaken them about 32 miles from here, having covered this distance in 24 hours. He reported that the Lower River was in flood stage and he met extreme difficulty in crossing, but the boys were suffering from hunger and exposure, having become thoroughly soaked crossing so he built a fire and rested a few hours during which Bourassa stated that they were in some danger, as the reserve has recently been burned over and the brush is very thick.

4. On this date I interviewed a thorough warning not to repeat this attempt.

Fyle numbers must be quoted.

4. Con't (I also) discussed with Father HUGERRE the question of preventing further attempts by any of the children to run away from the school. I suggested that a more careful watch be maintained during the recess periods, and if it was necessary, a more frequent Roll-Call when the children are gathered in large groups.

5. I wish to respectfully draw attention to the sense of responsibility and efficiency displayed by S/Ost. Bourassa on this case. His natural ability to follow tracks and his determination not to overtake these boys before they reached the open prairie, did much to effect their safe return. On the return trip it was necessary for him to give them food as they had not eaten for 26 hours and were in an exhausted condition. Team was hired at a flat rate of $3.00 per diem.

EXCERPT from letter of Doctor H. A. Hamman, Fort Vermilion, dated January 20th, 1940.

More and more children are being brought into the school (Fort Vermilion Residential) in accordance with your instructions that various adults will lose ration rights if their children or grandchildren are not placed therein. Accommodation is taxed to the utter limit and more are coming. Not a single cot is now available. But, more important, the health of all is going to be seriously affected if more are entered as the cubic air space of dormitories and school rooms is already asked to do too much to keep up a steady amount of fresh air for all. The Mission will have to enlarge its premises if the school population grows very much more. The Mission authorities have not mentioned the matter to me in this strain. I do know any further influx should be stopped at once. There is however, one child, a girl, daughter of Julie Toby, now in hospital, that I would like to place in school as soon as she is well, as she was a pitifully wasted spectacle when she arrived - also her mother is a ne'er do well.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) H. A. Hamman.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I acknowledge receipt of your letter of Feb. 6, 1931-18-10.

The complaints made by Dr. Newman caused me to write immediately to Father Principal at Fort Vermillion about the apparent serious situation developing at his School. Be sure, Father Bureuerr will remedy that overcrowding condition as soon as possible. I cannot understand how things happened, unless many children have come all at once from the Little Red River.

As we know, it is known that the number of Indian children is increasing everywhere, and this should be considered as the most eloquent and irrefutable plea in favor of the excellent work done by the Residential Schools for the rehabilitation of the Indian tribes. At the same time, this increase in number creates new conditions in our schools; some of them have to be replaced without delay, because tottering and entirely lacking modern accommodations as it is the case at Sturgeon Lake, others have to be emptied of all other social services which until now had been sheltered therein, as it is the case at Fort Vermillion where a small hospital has occupied for years a good portion of floor-space.

It is perfectly evident that the existing possible floor-space of the School must be from this consecrated to house our Indian children only. This will be done, I hope, in the near future, if the Department gives me a little helping hand.

First, in connection with the class rooms, the situation will be remedied next summer by the building of a separate school of 2 class rooms for Breed pupils, so that the existing class rooms will be exclusively used for our Indian children. A concrete foundation has been already put in this Fall and the new separate school should be finished early next Spring.

Secondly, the dormitories will certainly give ample cubic air per child in residence, when the space occupied by the Hospital is restored to the School children. I am working on a report I promised Mr. Jackson on the hospitalization problem at Fort Vermillion.

The need for a Hospital in that locality is evident and pressing. There is 1000 Indians in the District and the closest Hospital at hands is that of Peace River, 200 miles south by plane. We did our best, in the circumstances, to alleviate the situation and, as there was ample room at the time in our Residential School building, a portable ward on the floor was placed in which has been used since as a temporary Hospital, where two and often more nurses are on constant duty.

Now, the number of children having increased and the hospital accommodations having become inadequate, it is time something is done and a modern Hospital of about 15 beds is built.

With this end in view, I had a sketch prepared and I intend to ask the Hon. Minister, through his Secretary Mr. Jackson, for a grant of at least 50% of the total cost of the building. Dear Mr. Hoey, I know you can do much to assure the success of this scheme and I am sure that you will help me, as I have written you at each length and end this letter praying you to intercede in favor of the immediate construction of this much needed Hospital at Fort Vermillion, so that the sick people of the District may receive the proper care to which they are entitled, and at the same time no School age children be deprived of education.

With my best personal regards,

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 19th instant, in connection with a communication received from Mr. S.C. Dineen, copy of which you have supplied me with.

I am informed by the District Inspector of Provincial Schools that Mr. Dineen is a school teacher at a school located about 20 miles from the town of Fort Vermilion. He does not remember the name of the place nor of the school district but I presume it must be in the fairly well settled district north-west of Fort Vermilion where the Ukrainian element predominates.

As you have directed him to me, I am not communicating with him.

Yours very truly,

N. P. L'Heureux,

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter here inclosed, dated November 30, 1942, here is a rough estimate of the expenses for the transportation of the children to and from the Fort Vermilion School.

I-For transportation TO Fort Vermilion School:
There are two groups of children we must pick up every fall: one from Reserve no. 162, the other from Reserve no. 173.

1-From Reserve 162, at Red River, there are 25 to 35 children coming to our school. This reserve is 75 milles down the Peace River; and to reach the Reserve we have to go over 12 milles portage at Fort Vermilion Chutes. Moreover in the early fall many families are out in the woods in quest of their living. In those circumstances the round trip will take seven days:

a-A freighter with his own boat will not make that trip for less than $50.00. $50.00
b-We estimate that the care and food for one child are at cost $.50 per day; for 30 children with an average of 3 days care for each child: $45.00. 45.00
c-trip east of the same Reserve by Sping lake, Stinking River, Moose Lake; four days with a guide and his horse; at $5.00 per day: $20.00 20.00

2-From Reserve 173. This Reserve is 75 milles south of Fort Vermilion. The means of communication is a very bad summer trail.

a-The round trip will take at least 6 days at $6.00 per day for the team and the driver: $36.00 36.00
b-The care & food for 8 children at $1.50 12.00

II-For transportation FROM Fort Vermilion School:
To return home the children it is much easier because their parents have some money on hand in the spring with the closing of the trapping season and they come often half way to meet us, generally at Fort Vermilion Chutes. In these circumstances, to return home the children the total expense should not exceed $40.00 40.00

Total....... $203.00
Then the total amount required for the transportation of the children to and from Fort Vermilion School would be about $203.00.

If during the past years those expenses were lower it is only because the missionary, who was using his own boat, did not charge his time and the use of his boat; but when we travel with the Hudson Bay Company's boat or any body else's boat, we must pay the fare and this expense have to be figured out in the total estimate.

Hoping that the Department will take in favorable consideration our request,

I remain,

Sincerely yours,

Rev. B. Rainville, O.M.I.

Re: Truant Indian Children - Fort Vermilion Residential School

Reference your letters January 23rd, and April 15th. The pupils showing as absentees on the School Quarterly Returns are all, with the exception of a few listed in this letter, from Little Red River Reserve and the parents absolutely refused to send them back to school last September, giving for reasons the long distance and the high cost to go and see their children at Fort Vermilion.

The Department is no doubt aware of the distance and particularly of the difficulties existing on the road between Fort Vermilion and Little Red River. From Ft. Vermilion to the Chutes the trip is being made by boat, then about 15 miles by horses and to reach the Indians' homes several modes of transportation have to be used; horse back, canoe, etc., and the cost of a full trip is excessive. If you refer to reports submitted by the Fort Vermilion Mission in connection with trips taken to recruit the Red River school children in the past years you will have be in a better position to understand the situation.

The mission made three trips last Fall but with very little success, even with the co-operation of the Chief who has a great deal of influence over his band, but they have not been able to convince the Indians to release their children. When visiting this Reserve at Treaty time I generally make it a point to emphasize the necessity of sending their children to school, knowing their attitude, but all this has very little bearing on them, and the only solution I can see to this problem is the law, and I will not take steps unless instructed by the Indian Department to do so.

RE: Indian Departments School Attendance - Treaty Indian Children, R.C.Mission School - Pt.Vermillion, Alta.

(1) On the 31-8-47, Fr.Rainville, L/C R.C.Mission (Pt.Vermillion), reported to this detachment requesting that Indians in the district be advised of the opening date of the mission school for Indian children.

(2) Fr.Rainville stated in the past it had been the practice of the RCMP to warn all Indians of the importance of sending their children to school, that it had been the experience of the school in the past that if no warning was given parents of these children they would not attend, or would drift in to school as late as three weeks after the opening date. It was learned the opening date for the mission school was 1-9-47, this for registration and placement, that school classes would begin 5-9-47, therefore it was important that all children be on hand in time for classes.

(3) At 11 AM, 31-8-47, via hired car patrol was made to Stony Point district where A.Mizotte was hired as interpreter, and with him patrol continued to the Eleskie (Child Lake) Indian Reserve where the chief, councillors and parents were warned of the school opening and advised to have their children report accordingly.

(4) Patrol also covered the Bulldog Reserve where the same warning was issued, returning to Pt.Vermillion where scattered families were contacted and warned of the opening date. Posters supplied by the Mission advising all children over the age of 7 years and under 16 years to attend were posted in strategic places for the information of all who could read and pass the word to others.

(5) Patrol returned to detachment at 7-30 PM same date, advising the Mission of district covered.

(6) On the 1-9-47 Fr.Rainville called at this detachment stating he expected no further trouble with absentee's as they were arriving at the Mission as instructed, and requesting Indians reporting for rations from outlying points be checked as to the school attendance of their children. As it appears from reports the children are attending as desired it is considered no further action is required; consequently this file is being concluded.

Ottawa, March 23, 1948.

Dear Father Rainville:

Indian Superintendent Walker has submitted to us an account covering the cost of transportation of two girls transferred from the Vermilion Residential School to the Groizard Residential School. It is noted that these girls were sent by air.

Our records indicate that these girls were only fourteen years of age and in Grade V. Why was it apparently considered necessary to send them in the middle of the term? Would it not have been possible to defer their transfer until the end of June?

I would like to point out that owing to its cost we want to avoid as far as possible, moving children by air. If the transfer had been delayed until the end of June, their transportation would not likely have been necessary.

I would appreciate hearing from you in the matter. In the meantime, payment of the account will be withheld.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Sir:

YP: 131-13-10 (E.1)

In reply to your letter dated March the 23rd regarding the transportation of two girls to the Manual Training School at Grouard, I beg to advise as follows:

Albina Kidney is 16 years of age as she is born in November 1931. -- Albina Adekat will be 15 years of age; she is born in April 1933.

These two girls in my opinion were well prepared to profit by the special course given at Grouard's School. Both of them were glad to leave their relatives for the sake of a better education, but Albina Kidney would not have accepted to go alone; so for the sake of giving the older girl a better education, I thought I was justified to send with her a companion that was able to profit by the course.

It is true that I could have waited for the River Transportation and then cut in half the transportation costs.... At the end of December, Indian Superintendent Walker requested that I should take in the school the Beaulieu's family, Uppa Ha River Band no. 226, orphans, the mother had died few days before. As I had not a bed vacant my only alternative was to discharge older pupils. Helen Attillon (16 years old) was discharged and returned home; and the two mentioned girls were immediately transferred to Grouard and I wrote immediately to the Department for approval.

Yours very truly,

Rev. B. Rainville, O.M.I.

July 21, 1950.

Reverend Paul Serrand,
Principal,
Fort Vermilion Indian Residential School,
Fort Vermilion, Alta.

Dear Father Serrand:

The June Quarterly Return for Fort Vermilion Indian Residential School is returned as it will not be possible for the Department to put it through Treasury for payment in the present form.

You have shown a number of pupils to be in residence for 84 days. It is presumed that these pupils have completed their academic work and left for home before the end of June.

The practice followed by the Department for cases of this nature is to claim full grant on the June Quarter and make the adjustment on the September Quarter, for it is probable that the pupils who left the residence early might return early and this would make it impossible to adjust on the return.

Please adjust the attached return accordingly and return. In the meantime we are forwarding you a part payment of $4,000.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. Paul Serrand,
Fort Vermilion Indian Res. School,
Fort Vermilion, Alta.,

I have your September Quarterly Return.

On checking this return it is noted that you are showing a number of pupils who have been out of residence for one reason or another, in some cases up to three years. This practice is not satisfactory as the return shows there is a larger number of pupils in residence than actually enrolled.

It is suggested, therefore, that you apply to the Department by Form I.A. 411 for the approval of the discharge of all pupils who, in your estimation are not returning to school at all or those who will probably not return within the next six months.

In the event of any pupils returning after being discharged you will be obliged to secure authority from the Department to re-admit them. You will note that you show the enrolment at the school to be 119 pupils while the average is 76. You can see the discrepancy.

On your September Admission and Discharge Form you have shown that thirteen children have been admitted to the school for institutional care. On checking our files, it is noted that no applications for the admission of these children have been received in this office, consequently their admittance to the school has not been approved. Technically, the Department is not obliged
to allow per capita grant on children whose admission to school has not been approved. However, we will allow the September grant on the understanding that the applications for admission will be received shortly.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

Colonel Bernard F. Neary,
superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Quarterly Return - Fort Vermilion Indian Residential School.

Attached hereto is quarterly return for the quarter ending December 31st, 1950. Also attached are Application for Admission forms.

You will note that a great number of these forms are not signed by the parents. I would like to point out the difficulties encountered in getting the children to school. In the fall of the year the Indians of this Agency are scattered throughout the bush on moose hunts and the problem of getting the children in to school always has been a difficult one. This year I put the onus on the Chiefs and Councillors. They rounded up the children and brought them to school. As the Chiefs and Councillors cannot read or write, it would be very difficult for them to take a set of forms and obtain signatures. Therefore, I would assume that if the Chief or Councillor brought in the children, they came with the parents' consent.

It will be physically impossible to get a lot of these forms signed before the spring. I am therefore sending them in without the signatures of the parents. I feel that if we ask the Chief and Councillors to bring in the children and we then tax their efforts by giving them a lot of forms to sign which they do not understand, we may run into difficulties. I would therefore ask you to accept them as they are. The Indians of this Agency at Fox Lake do not like to send their children to school as they are out of contact.
Colonel Neary

Re: Vermilion Indian Residential School

We received your letter of the 3rd instant, with reference to transportation of children to the above school. In view of the contents of your letter, I do not consider that any further payment is due Jean Courtoiselle.

With particular reference to the second last paragraph of your letter, I feel that it would be inadvisable to threaten the Indians with a statement to the effect that if they do not send their children to school, their Family Allowances will be stopped.

I feel very definitely that you should confine your efforts at the present time to insisting on having all children of school age attend school. If your requests in this regard are not carried out when school accommodation is available, you should then be guided by the provisions of the Family Allowance Act.

Philip Phelan,

I am in receipt of your letter of July 23rd in which you enclosed copy of a letter received from Jean Courtoisielle.

In previous years, one of the Fathers from the Mission St. Henri brought the children to school after rounding them up and submitted an account. I do not know of any time when the Mission was paid $300.00 for a trip one way. However, in 1950 we paid a bill amounting to $328.20 - our Voucher No. 8 of January 10th, 1950, to the Mission St. Henri. This included the cost of taking the children to their homes at the end of the school term in June, 1949, and of bringing them back to school in the fall of 1949. On this trip, Father Jean was accompanied by a Sister. The purpose of this was to explain to the children and parents the reason for the children to attend school in the hope that in future years less effort and cost would be expended in bringing the children to school. On this trip 38 children were brought in. There was a considerable amount of bad weather experienced on this trip, which delayed them. Also included in this amount of $328.20 was $40.00 for the transportation over the portage by Mr. R. A. Barrett. As the Indians own sufficient teams, they should be prepared to transport them over the portage free of charge.

Last summer, Father Serrand - the Principal of the school - said that he was unwilling to take over this work. It was also felt that the Chiefs and Councillors of this Band should accept the responsibility of seeing that a sufficient number of children were sent to the Indian Residential School.
This was thoroughly discussed at a Council Meeting and the Chief deputized Councillor Jean Courtoisielle to see the children were brought in. I agreed with Jean Courtoisielle that he be given the sum of $80.00 to defray the cost of gas, etc., for taking the children and that he was to get the full support of the rest of the Band. Jean Courtoisielle finally brought in 32 children. He then pointed out to me that the $80.00 was not sufficient. Because of the effort he had made, I reviewed the situation and offered to pay his bills plus $25.00 for his labor. I refer you to our Voucher No. 438 of October 24, 1950, in the amount of $70.00 (made payable to the Hudson's Bay Company, Fort Vermilion), which involved the cost of gas, oil and food. I supplied him with sufficient gas to return to Little Red River. This is accounted for under our Voucher No. 67 - payable to Mrs. M. Batt, Fort Vermilion, Alta., under date of January 19th, 1951, in the amount of $10.80.

We also paid him an additional sum of $25.00 which is part of our Voucher No. 89, payable to the Hudson's Bay Company, under date of January 19th, 1951.

A few more children were later brought in by Francis Meneen, another Indian, for the sum of $15.00. Mr. R. A. Barnett also was paid the sum of $8.00 for transporting these last children over the portage - our Voucher No. 130 of February 22, 1951. The amount of $15.00 paid to Francis Meneen is included in our Voucher No. 89 of January 19th, 1951, payable to the Hudson's Bay Company. This makes a total of $128.80 for bringing in less than 40 children.

An agreement was made with the Councillor, as he well knows, and we went further than this by giving him additional money for his efforts. I do not think we should have to pay a Councillor for work which is part of his duties and for which no other Councillor is paid. These people must be made to realize that the people of the Ambroise Tete Hoir Band at Childs Lake have to bring their children a distance of thirty miles to the school and never have received a nickel in payment. The people of the Tallcree Band live a distance of sixty-five miles from Fort Vermilion. They bring their children to school in the fall and take them home at the close of school in the spring and have never been paid anything for doing this.

I think it is only reasonable and fair to expect that in future the people of the Cree Band at Fox Lake be held responsible for bringing their children to the end of the portage at their own expense and that we should assume the expense for
transporting them from the end of the portage to Fort Vermilion, which I believe can be done for less than $20.00.

I cannot say where Jean Courtorielle got his information of the Mission being paid $300.00. In any case, it was understood that Jean Courtorielle would see that the children were brought to school as his duty as a Councillor and we did not make any arrangements to hire him individually for the sole purpose of bringing in the children.

With your permission I would like to take a stronger stand on this matter this year and notify the people that the children must be at the portage on a certain date and that they should undertake that part of the journey at their own cost. There are sufficient wagons, teams and boats amongst these Indians to enable them to bring all the children to the end of the portage without involving the Department in any expense. If we are getting such good co-operation from the other Bands in the Agency, it is only reasonable to expect the members of the Cree Band to do the same.

I would therefore suggest that we inform the Chief's and Councillors that the pupils must be at the end of the portage on a certain date and that all those not there on that particular date will be considered as absentees, their Family Allowance stopped and action taken for absentee pupils.

I am sending you two copies of this letter in case you wish to send one copy to Mr. Jean Courtorielle with your comments.

S. C. Knapp,
Superintendent.

I do not think we should have to pay a Councillor for work which is part of his duties and for which no other Councillor is paid. These people must be made to realize that the people of the Amoraise Tete Noir band at Childs Lake have to bring their children a distance of thirty miles to the school and never have received a nickel in payment. The people of the Talloree Band live a distance of sixty-five miles from Fort Vermilion. They bring their children to school in the fall and take them home at the close of school in the spring and have never been paid anything for doing this.

I think it is only reasonable and fair to expect that in future the people of the Cree Band at Fox Lake be held responsible for bringing their children to the end of the portage at their own expense and that we should assume the expense for
transporting them from the end of the portage to Fort Vermilion, which I believe can be done for less than $50.00.

I cannot say where Jean Courtoiselle got his information of the Mission being paid $300.00. In any case, it was understood that John Courtoiselle would see that the children were brought to school as his duty as a Councillor and we did not make any arrangements to hire him individually for the sole purpose of bringing in the children.

With your permission I would like to take a stronger stand on this matter this year and notify the people that the children must be at the portage on a certain date and that they should undertake that part of the journey at their own cost. There are sufficient wagons, teams and boats amongst these Indians to enable them to bring all the children to the end of the portage without involving the Department in any expense. If we are getting such good co-operation from the other bands in the Agency, it is only reasonable to expect the members of the Cree Band to do the same.

I would therefore suggest that we inform the Chiefs and Councillors that the pupils must be at the end of the portage on a certain date and that all those not there on that particular date will be considered as absentees, their family allowance stopped and action taken for absentee pupils.

I am sending you two copies of this letter in case you wish to send one copy to Mr. Jean Courtoiselle with your comments.

S. G. Knapp,
Superintendent.

15th, October, 1951.

Mr Philip Phelan
Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re; Fort Vermilion Residential School Quarterly Returns.

Attached please find the Quarterly Returns for the above mentioned school for the quarter ending 30th, September, 1951.

You will note that only a few of the Application for Admission forms have been completed. Most of those outstanding are the pupils from Little Red River and the Fox Lake Reserve District. Every year we have to make a round up trying to get the children in. With one group we sent the chief to bring them in and he can neither read nor write. Therefore the problem of getting the Admission Forms signed is very difficult.

Father Serand has assured me that the Rev. Father Vanderstein the Resident priest will do all he can during the next three months to get these forms signed by the parents.

At the present there are over twenty children that should be in school as the Rev. Father Serand assures me there is accommodation for them. I have already written to the Regional office requesting further instructions with regard to taking stronger action to bring these pupils in. Most of them are boys.

Under the above circumstances and owing to the difficulties that we encounter in bringing these children in from isolated and widely scattered camps it would be appreciated if the grant could be passed. Owing to the rising costs of living the school finds it difficult to meet its financial obligations.

With reference to the day school pupils. All the Meneens have poor living conditions and it my opinion that they should be made to attend a residential school pupils and it is possible that...
In the near future that we can get the agreement of the parents to put these children in residence without resorting to stronger measures. Accommodation was reserved for them, therefore as these pupils were in residence last year it would be appreciated if you would give consideration to the granting of the per capita summer grant for these pupils. On the present forms the principal crossed them out. If you are in agreement with the above, the forms could be amended.

With regards to Rose Chambaud Pupil number 0326, this child was discharged from Camsell Hospital and admitted under instructions from Dr Falconer and Mr Gooderham. This child speaks English and will be six in January.

Mr Utz decided to try and open a day school at Little Red River just as we were trying to get the pupils to the residential school. This has caused us a great deal of extra effort in trying to get the pupils to school. It has further confused the Indians. Mr Utz has not declared his religious beliefs and has this band of Indians are all Catholic with only a couple exceptions it has presented a very difficult problem. This problem should be handled with a great deal of firmness.

Many of our Indians still believe that they are doing the church a favour by sending their children to the residential school instead of complying with the law.

Mr Waller of the Regional office was at Little Red River to deal with this problem and is being kept informed.

S.C. Knapp
Superintendent.

Fort Vermilion, Alta.

Father Serrand has assured me that the Rev. Father Vanderstein the Resident priest will do all he can during the next three months to get these forms signed by the parents.

At the present there are over twenty children that should be in school as the Rev. Father Serrand assures me there is accommodation for them. I have already written to the Regional Office requesting further instructions with regard to taking stronger action to bring these pupils in. Most of them are boys.

Under the above circumstances and owing to the difficulties that we encounter in bringing these children in from isolated and widely scattered camps it would be appreciated if the grant could be passed. Owing to the rising costs of living the school finds it difficult to meet its financial obligations.

With reference to the day school pupils. All the Meneens have poor living conditions and it my opinion that they should be made to attend as residential school pupils, and it is possible that in the near future we can get agreement of the parents to put these children in residence without resorting to stronger measures. Accommodation was reserved for them, therefore as these pupils were in residence last year, it would be appreciated if you would give consideration to the granting of the per capital summer grant for these pupils. On the present forms the Indigal crossed them out. If you are in agreement with the above the forms could be amended.

Attention Inspector Waller,

Re: Truancy - Fox Lake Band.

I wish to report the progress made to date in bringing in the truants of the Fox Lake Reserve District.

A plane had to be sent to Fifth Meridian on Thursday December 6th to pick up a very sick Indian boy for hospital. The R.C.M.P. went along on this plane to visit Fifth Meridian and Little Red River to deal with truancy. The weather closed in and we were forced to stay at Little Red River overnight.

The R.C.M.P. served truant notices for twenty-six children. Six children were brought back and admitted to school. Three of these children were attending Mr. Utz's school. Four other children have since been sent into residence, making a total of ten.

The truancy notices were made out to be effective on the twentieth December, owing to many of the men having to return to their trapping camps and bring their children back to Little Red River as the assembly point.

The cost of bringing in these children by caboose or bombadier was carefully worked out. The bombadier was found to be the cheaper of the two. The bombadier will therefore leave on the twentieth to bring the children to the Fort.

The R.C.M.P. will also go along on this trip in case the Moose Lake Indians have failed to carry out the orders on the truant notices. In which case the bombadier will proceed to Moose Lake to pick them up.
Investigations have been made into some of the homes of parents sending their children as day pupils. Where home conditions were found to be below requirements and destitution prevailed the children have been ordered into residence.

We will report further after the twentieth. It must be remembered that these children are scattered in six different camps and are difficult to reach.

You can rest assured that everything possible is being done to get these children into school and we hope to be able to say on our next report that this school is filled.

Mr. C.C. Knapp,

Fort Vermilion, Alta.,

With reference to the June Quarterly Return for the Fort Vermilion Indian Residential School, it is noted that pupils 0262, 241, 243, 246, 281, 285 and 307 were in hospital for a short period of time during the quarter. As all of these children except pupil # 281 were in hospital for less than thirty days full grant of 31 days was allowed for each of them.

As pupil # 281 was admitted to hospital on May 14th the Principal should have claimed 74 days which was allowed as this pupil was in residence for 44 days plus 30 days hospital grant which is allowed. It is noted that pupil # 0142 was admitted to residence after discharge from hospital on May 13, consequently the school is entitled to 48 days grant rather than 44 as indicated by the Principal.

For pupil # 313 the Principal has shown in the Remarks Column that this pupil was admitted to hospital on May 8 and discharged on May 29 while he has only claimed 37 days grant for this pupil. It is evident that this child was also in the Charles Cassell Hospital but the Principal has neglected to indicate the dates in this regard. We are consequently disallowing any grant for this pupil as the data available is not sufficient to pay the Per Capita Allowance for this pupil on the June Return. Please advise the Principal that it will be in order for him to claim 37 days grant on the September Return together with the
grant for which the school is entitled for this pupil for the September Quarter, but the Principal will have to explain in the Remarks Column the circumstances for claiming the 37 days.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

October 7, 1952.

Mr. S.C. Knapp,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Fort Vermilion, Alta.,

With reference to the September Quarterly Return for the Fort Vermilion Indian Residential School, we do not appear to have the necessary application for admission for pupil 331 Leo Courtereille; consequently we are disallowing any grant for him on the September Return. It would be appreciated if you would arrange to have this application forwarded to this office for approval and when it is approved ask the Principal to include this boy's name on the December Quarterly Return claiming grant for him for the month of September and for the number of days the school is entitled to for the December Quarter.

Pupil # 0334 was not in residence during the month of June as she was in the Charles Camsell Hospital consequently the school is not entitled to per capita grant for the months of July and August. We are, therefore, allowing thirty days grant for this pupil.

The Principal has neglected to indicate the dates the pupils were absent from residence. If you will bring the Principal's attention to our circular he will note that in all instances where pupils are in residence for less than the prescribed number of days for the quarter, an explanation must be given and the dates when the pupil left the residence and when he returned to residence. In the case of the September Return the Principal neglected to indicate the dates for pupils 243 and 294.
Please refer to our letter of July 30, third paragraph regarding pupil # 313 for whom the Principal claimed thirty-seven days grant on the June Return on which the Department disallowed as there was insufficient information to indicate the circumstances why the Principal claimed thirty-seven days grant for him. The Principal has again claimed thirty-seven days grant but failed to show the dates that the pupil left the residence and later returned to residence and the reason for the absences, consequently we are disallowing the thirty-seven days requested.

Please instruct the Principal that he may claim this grant on the December Return but a definite explanation must be provided before the Department will allow the grant.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Sir:

In a letter dated July 26th, the Principal of our Wabasca School states that during the visit of the Treaty party to that School on July 23rd-25th, he directed the attention of the Indian Agent to the additional space which was being provided for pupils through the erection of a new class-room, and further states that the Indian Agent promised to recommend to your Department an increase in the pupilage. At the present time the official capacity as sanctioned by your Department is 30, and as the Principal points out that there are more than 12 pupils ready to come in, and that there is accommodation for at least 15, our Commission recommends that the official capacity be increased to 45 from the 1st of September next. As he reports that the Indian councillors at a meeting, urged that the increase be granted, our Commission sincerely hope that their recommendation may be accepted, and the increase authorized from the date mentioned.

In my letter of January 18th last, I endeavoured to place before your Department, not only the urgent need of an increased pupilage at this school, but the need of a new building to replace the one which was built by our Church many years ago. I also furnished an estimate of the cost of building and equipping a new log building, fixing the total cost at approximately $7,000. In your reply on January 25th, 131-8-1, you referred to the possibility of consideration being given to this matter when the supplementary estimates were being prepared.

As I have not heard anything further from you in this connection, I can only conclude that no provision was made in the supplementary estimates for this urgently needed improvement.

Until a new and larger school can be provided, our Commission feel strongly that they are justified in asking for the
increased pupilage, seeing that they have provided the increased accommodation, and it is very earnestly hoped that the increase requested may be sanctioned.

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General-

1. Beauval, Sask.
2. Albany Mission, Fort Albany, Ont.
3. Providence Mission, Fort Providence, N.W.T.
4. St Bernard, Grouard, Alta.
5. Vermillion, Fort Vermillion, Alta.
6. Sturgeon Lake, Calais, Alta.
7. Wabasca C.E., Wabasca, Alta.
8. Wabasca R.C., Desmarais, Alta.
9. Whitefish Lake, Atikameg, Alta.
10. St Bruno, Jossard, Alta.

The above is a partial list of residential schools in connection with which the Department pays a per capita grant. In these cases the Department did not build the schools and does not exercise the rights of ownership. It is noted that the last seven in the above list are in one agency i.e. the Grouard Agency.

In a number of these cases the Department is being asked to assume financial responsibility and to pay grants towards the capital costs of the buildings, besides making additional grants for additions, repairs and maintenance. In at least some instances there are undertakings on the part of the Department to furnish certain social assistance. Many of the engagements made in the past in this connection have been verbal in nature and the terms are not of definite record. It would seem clear, however, that in some, if not all cases the Department is obligated to some degree at least, but the lack of written records and agreements makes it very difficult to determine the nature and extent of this responsibility.

The fact that the Department has undertaken the payment of per capita grants implies a certain responsibility for the up-keep of the buildings, if not for the capital costs.

In my opinion it is necessary that the Department adopt a general policy for the purpose of dealing with these difficulties and I would respectfully offer the following suggestions for your consideration:
1. That the Department of Indian Affairs undertake the payment of per capital grants and any financial aid towards the cost of building only when the prior authority of the Department has been granted. This authority should cover such matters as site, size and nature of school buildings.

2. That such authority in all cases be set out in a formal and definitely worded agreement for the guidance of Departmental officials, as a matter of record and for the purpose of avoiding future misunderstandings.

3. That the schools now operating by authority of the Department as recognized by the payment of per capita grants be assisted from time to time as circumstances warrant and financial conditions permit.

4. That the various missionary societies be notified of the above rulings.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

Harold W. McGill.
Deputy Superintendent General.

CALGARY, ALTA. August 2nd, 1933.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection of the Church of England School situated on Wabasca Lake up near what they call the "Narrows," about five miles from the Roman Catholic School.

On my arrival there I found there was no Principal in charge and the work was being carried on by the Matron. This is a very old building, having been built out of logs a great many years ago, and it is in a very poor state of repair. The floors are worn and as a whole the building is very dilapidated.

There are 32 children in residence. In the classroom there are only 19 seats; the rest are benches. The classroom is heated by two stoves, and they have only a small blackboard. The teacher in charge of the classroom was Miss A. C. Bloomer, who holds a second class certificate. She is a very capable teacher and I feel that good work is being performed. There are 22 pupils in Grade I, 4 in Grade II and 4 in Grade III.

Doctor Harold W. McGill,

Dear Sir:

Our Commission have received from the Rev. J. M. Roe, B.A., Acting-Principal of our Wabasca School, a report on his visit during the month of February, to the Long Lake district, which is approximately 87 miles from Wabasca. On this visit he was accompanied by the Manager of the local Hudson's Bay Company's Post, and also by Nurse Bawden, who was able to administer treatment to some sixty Indians requiring medical attention.

In addition to visiting Indian families on the way to and from Long Lake, Mr. Roe was enabled while at Long Lake to visit the Indian settlements at Good Fish Lake, Goose Grass Lake, and Round Lake, and to secure much valuable information about the Indians, both Treaty and Non-Treaty, in Treaty District No. 8.

With regard to the number of people in Treaty District No. 8, Mr. Roe writes as follows:

"In this Treaty district (No. 8) there are supposed to be 650 souls receiving Treaty. There are quite 100 souls not receiving Treaty, but who are entitled to it. There are perhaps 50 souls in Indian families, who took out scrip. The non-treaty people in the same area would probably number 400 souls. (Wabasca voters list gives 100 names; and the Desmarais list about 100 names). The total population of the area would therefore be approximately 1200 souls."

As his report deals chiefly with the Indians in the Long Lake and adjacent settlements, I beg to inform you that he states there are some 25 Treaty children of school age in that

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6377, file 767-1, part 1)
area, and that none of these have ever "been entered in either of the schools, E.C. or R.C." In the family of an Indian named "Thunder Spirit", for instance, he states there are 7 children, all of whom, except the two youngest, have been baptized by our missionaries, and as the family "are always in a state of semi-starvation" the father and mother allowed him to take two of the children back to our Wabasca School with him.

Mr. Roe's report enumerates other families as well having children of school age, but he makes special reference to the following eight children which have "a special claim for our consideration", and which should be admitted to our school this Fall:

"Caroline Auger, age 7, daughter of Alexis and Agnes. Both parents were pupils in our School. Alexis "went over" to the R.C. Mission after leaving School. They were married by the R.C. priest. But the old association and allegiance returned, and their boy, Alphonse, now aged 9 was put into our School. They were "promised" that Caroline should come in this Fall.

Lilian Orr, age 7, daughter of George Orr. His boy, Bobby, age 12 is in School, and there are two children younger than Lilian.

Joseph Auger, age 7, son of Usta Grasshead and Gertie (Aloek). Gertie was at this School, Usta was at the R.C. School. They wish their boy to be brought up here.

John Nanimehoo, son of (age 7) Maxley, an Old Boy of this School. Maxley is generally in need of help; he has five children. This boy should come in to School in the Fall.

Basil Nanimehoo, age 7, son of Pierre. One of a large family, (we have Katherine, Michael, Harvey and Mary Ann all of this family, in the School now) and the parents are generally in need of help.

Elizabeth Beaver, age 9, daughter of Councillor Martin Beaver, (we have Daniel and Florence in school now) and the Agent gave injunction to Martin that the child must come to School this year.

Violet Cat, age 7, daughter of Johnny Cat, of the Reserve here. (we had Benwa, age 16, and Caroline, 19, in the School a few years ago). There are two or three younger children.

Mary Lenore Oar, age 7, daughter of Max Oar, on the Reserve here. There are two younger children, and Max cannot keep his family in necessities."

As the school has a sanctioned capacity of 30 pupils only, and has a capacity enrolment at present, our Commission strongly recommend that the official capacity be increased to 40. With regard to the accommodation Mr. Roe writes, in part, as follows:

"But I am confident that we can provide accommodation here, with adjustments of space, etc., for 40 children, and so admit the 9 children I have listed, (in the Fall) plus the "Beaver" child whose mother at God's Lake is begging for her to be brought here. For the sum of $100 we can make all the necessary alterations, etc., and by vigorous work through the Spring and Summer, we can be ready in the Fall."

STATEMENT CONCERNING MAINTENANCE OF INDIAN SCHOOLS.

We anticipate a total Treaty Indian Children of not less than 40 in attendance at the three schools, (Wabasca, St. Peter's, St. Andrew's)

This number would undoubtedly increase if the Missionary staff could be strengthened.

Fishing is now an active business conducted by commercial companies of whitemen. Before they were established whitefish could be procured in abundance and at small cost. It formed the staple article of diet with variation of Moose meat, bacon or beef.

All meat is now excessively high in cost and fish not less so.

Abnormal prices prevail for flour and other necessary commodities without which the children cannot be maintained in health.

The cost of provisions in each Mission has risen proportionately. Salaries have been increased in some cases.

The payment of all labour connected with the missions has extended.

A grant for each child of twice the amount made in 1910, ($125 per annum) would not much more than equalize the conditions prevailing then and now.

A generous increase is absolutely needed.

E.A. Robins
(Bishop)

Ottawa, February 15th, 1910.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Bishop Holmes, of Athabasca, has renewed the request for an increased grant to the Church of England Boarding Schools at Wabiskaw Lake and Whitefish Lake, Treaty 8, and for a day school grant at Peace River.

We have lately made them a day school grant at Lesser Slave Lake and in 1904-05 a grant of $300.00 for the Peace River school was voted. No returns were received from December, 1907, till December, 1909. The latter was received a few days ago and payment has been made.

While I would not recommend making an exception in favour of these two boarding schools in the matter of per capita grant I am of opinion that the question of an increase in the pupilage is worthy of consideration.

The returns from the Wabiakaw school show that in the June quarter, last, there were enrolled 37 pupils and in the December quarter 19. His Lordship claims that this reduction was made because they could not afford to keep any in excess of the number for which the Department will pay the grant; not because of any lack of pupils. There has also been a reduction in the number maintained at Whitefish Lake.

There are several arguments that might be advanced in favour of an increased pupilage at these points.

In the first place the same staff is required to conduct a school for 15, the number now allowed, as for 25, pupils, the number asked for.

The cost of supplies in these outlying posts is very high, caused principally by the excessive freight rates.

Day schools are and for sometime will be impracticable in this district, as the Indians will depend upon the hunt for their living for years yet.

They have accommodation for the increased number asked for.

The earnings of 15 pupils are evidently not sufficient to finance a school. The Bishop states that last year he expended $4000.00, collected by him in England, in paying deficits that had accrued. The deficit at Wabiskaw for the year ended June 30th, last, was said to be $1000.00. I may here add that the Roman Catholic school at Wabiskaw Lake receives a grant for 25 pupils.

Mr. Inspector Conroy has reported very favourably on the work being done by these two schools and I would recommend that provision be made in the supplementary estimates for a grant of $73.00 to 10 additional pupils each at Wabiskaw and Whitefish Lake.
Dear SIR,

While at Wapuskow I carefully went into the financial condition of the Indian Boarding Schools and with the exercise of the strictest economy I find that it will be absolutely impossible to continue under present circumstances. As I have before represented the same staff of workers is required for fifteen scholars as would serve for twenty five, and the cost of upkeep and equipment almost the same we have reduced the number of scholars from thirty four to 25 and still the grant of $72.00 for fifteen will not cover more than half of the expenditure, this also applies to White Fish Lake.

We are obliged to refuse the Children of Scrip Indians when they are beginning to learn the mistake they have made and want what it means to be a white man. The workers are anxious to know what is to be the future of the school before June next, as they must look out for new situations if the school is to be closed.

I once again plead with the Department to make us a grant for $25 in each of the three schools viz-Wapuskown, and White Lake & make a lump sum grant
for Peace River School, where there are six treaty children in residence, as you have so kindly done for Lesser Slave Lake, thus we would be able to continue the work instead of having to close the schools.

Within the last year, I have paid over $4000 of school arrears out of funds, I collected in England for the purpose, these funds are now exhausted so it would be no longer possible.

I have estimated that each pupil cost $100 for support, where is possible to have Day schools, I should close all the Boarding Schools at once but as the Agents are aware, a day school would not reach 1-10 of the children.

Trusting that the Department will once more favourably consider the urgent appeal.

(signed) Geo. Athabasca

Hon. Sir,

The Bishop of Athabasca desires respectfully to lay before you the position of affairs in the Indian Schools.

He assumed office in the Diocese last April, and has since personally visited, and on the spot gone most carefully into the conduct and upkeep of the following schools:

re Wapuskow School

Dear Friends,

I have just returned from an interesting and encouraging visit to Wapuskaw, our youngest Mission in the diocese.

It lies some 150 miles north and east of here. The journey had to be made with dogs. Our rate of travel averaged 30 miles a day.

Accompanied by Mr. A. S. White and an Indian guide, I left here Feb 3rd. We proceeded down the Athabasca river about twelve miles.

From this point we ascended to the height of land. Our road was a narrow track or trail cut through the woods calling for care and expert handling of the long narrow sleigh made of two flat strips of birch bound together with shaganappi, to prevent their gliding with the stems of trees and fallen trees.

About six miles from the river we camped for the first night. Pine brush was laid where the snow had been cleared away and a bright fire rendered the situation much more comfortable than the cold, and falling snow seemed to render possible. The following morning we started about an hour before day-light.

Our road lay over Muskeg making the travelling very rough. My sleigh was arranged so that I could ride when I liked. As I infinitely prefer depending on my own legs and was armed with a good pair of Loucheux snow-shoes, I burdened the dogs as little as possible. At times, however, I was thankful to ride as the pace of a good train of dogs keeps a man on the run the whole time. The Muskeg country terminated in what is called Muskeg Lake.

Beyond this point the country is, or rather was densely wooded. With the exception of a few patches of unburnt timber the whole country is burnt out along the route we travelled. How wide an area of timber has been thus destroyed last summer, it would be hard to say. About sunset we came out on 'Calling-lake'. This is a fine sheet of water some eight miles in breadth and from ten to fifteen miles length. White fish of a good quality are caught by the Indians in this lake. There are about four families here occupying small log shanties on the northern bank. We camped at one of these houses. As far as personal comfort is concerned I much prefer to lay my blankets on the pine brush by the camp fire. On the other hand we received a kind welcome.
I was promised the honor of the sole bedstead, while my companions slept on the floor. What was more to the point, I had an attentive audience of men and women to whom I set forth the way of salvation through Christ Jesus. One old Indian woman seized and kissed my hand when leaving, telling me she understood what I had said and that she loved the words. I could but lift up my heart in prayer that the words might by the Holy Spirit be so grafted inwardly both in her, and their hearts, that they might bring forth fruit to God's glory.

The following day we passed through a heavily timbered country but mostly barren. At many points we passed springs that overflowed the ice and snow and supplied us with refreshing drinks. Travelling on the run in winter is very thirsty work. The evening set in cold and windy, but our guide 'Strong paddle' selected a good camp among thick pine. He had us up two hours before daylight, for the toughest part of our journey. We had to cross 'the mountain' as the Indians call it. This necessitates crossing some very steep ravines, and sometimes sleighs, men and dogs would land at the bottom in a heap, the men only too glad if they escaped collision, in their rapid descent, with stems or stumps. 'Sandy Lake' was reached that night, and we again slept in an Indian house. After supper several came in from adjoining houses and squatted on the floor, offering a deeply interesting congregation. The following evening we arrived at the mission. It stands on a height of land, facing the narrow channel and swamp that connects the two Wapuskaw lakes. The Mission house built of pine logs, has thirty feet area, including within its four walls, dwelling rooms, Indian hall and school room. This serves to economise much labour and fuel.

Mr Weaver has about three acres fenced around the house and capable of cultivation. He has had to contend with great difficulties and has certainly done much more towards the completion of the building than seemed possible.

Wapuskaw is a unique little settlement in the very heart of the country, far removed from the ordinary routes of travel, accessible only by dog trains in winter and bark canoes in summer, on account of the swamps, muskegs and long portages that have to be traversed. Fish are plentiful in the numerous lakes.

It is a good fur country and deer are fairly plentiful. The first Sunday I was there, Feb 9th, we had a congregation of about forty people in the morn-
ing and nearly the same number in the afternoon. At the latter service I baptised four adults and three children. The following Tuesday I started with Mr. Weaver to visit a sick Indian across the further lake. The cold was severe on the open lake and the trip took us the best part of a day. We were well repaid however by the eagerness with which he drank in the message of a Saviour's love. He was evidently far gone in consumption and could only speak in a whisper. He asked for me to sit close by his side while one of his friends propped him up. When unable to sit up longer he would be laid down on his pillow, only to ask to be lifted up again to hear more. As the husband of more than one wife I postponed baptizing him until the Rev G. Holmes's arrival who being a fluent Cree speaker could fully explain to him the Christian rule. Unfortunately Mr Holmes's arrival was delayed and the day we had arranged to revisit him we heard of his death.

Mr Holmes arrived on the following Friday and the tale he had to tell is a sad commentary on these poor Indians unenlightened by the Gospel.

We had heard last November at the Landing of a Soto Indian who was practising medicine with the usual accompaniments of drumming and pretended intercourse with Spirits at one of these lakes called Moose Lake. He foretold that a Wetigo should arise that would destroy every one who did not join his religion and come and place themselves under his protection. Many families appear to have done so. It created a general terror and uneasiness through the country. The hunters dare not go out to their hunting grounds with their families. The Indians have a great terror of these so called Wetigoos or Cannibals, they believe that after eating human flesh their heart becomes a lump of ice and no one's life is safe from them. Absurd as all this seems to us, it is a real terror to the untutored Indian. Dim shadowy terrors, nursed amid the silence and solitudes of the woods, beset them on every side.

A Wapuskaw Indian started with his wife and children for Trout Lake in January. The account of what happened Mr Holmes had from the wife. At their last camp before reaching Trout Lake, her husband who appeared quite well and ate his supper, suddenly said to his wife "See look at that!" it is coming to me". He crouched under his blanket and from that moment was a lunatic.
He told his wife that one of the children looked to him like a young moose and he wanted to kill and eat it. The woman sat up all night not daring to lie down lest he should kill the children or her. Fancy the poor woman alone in the solitude of those dreary woods through all that terrible night!

Next day she proposed that he should go ahead while she drove the dogs. He consented for awhile and then suddenly stopped, saying that something stopped him and would not let him go on. She had then to go ahead.

Finally they reached Trout lake. The people in their terror left their homes and crowded into two buildings in one of which the supposed Wetigoo was placed. They all thought that he was the cannibal the Soto Indian had been prophesying should arise. They appear to have been in a state of abject terror.

He was with them nineteen days. They bound him with cords but these he snapped in his frenzy. Finally his own father advocated his being put to death.

They prevailed on an Indian who had the reputation of being a Medicine man to do the deed. According to their statement he was very unwilling and at first refused. At length on their repeated solicitations and the expression of their conviction that otherwise, as the predicted cannibal, he would destroy them, he struck him on the head with his axe. But it required a third stroke before the poor madman lay a corpse at their feet. Mr Holmes stated on his arrival there he found them still in terror. They had piled huge logs over his grave and dare not leave the two houses into which with their families they were crowded. The poor woman with her two children wished to return to Wapuskaw under Mr Holmes's care. She drove her own dogs; Mr H. lending her one of his robes to keep the children from freezing. On reaching camp that night they found that both her legs were badly frozen above the knees and they had to leave her and her children at an Indian's house which they reached the following evening. Before leaving Wapuskaw the father had expressed his intention of putting his two children to school with us. When the mother returns we shall, I trust, have the poor children. If some friends of the cause would only support the children, I feel sure that the blessing of him who is 'the Father of the fatherless and the husband of the widow' will be theirs. We have now seven Indian children at the school fed and clothed. We have no Government
grant whatever, nor help from any source for their support other than the kind gifts that come to this Mission in the bales. The mischief I am sorry to say may not stop at the killing of this man; a brother of his has been brooding over the sad occurrence. He has been telling his fellow Indians that his brother comes to him in his sleep. They in their turn are frightened lest he too should go out of his mind. Some however of his friends have come under Christian instruction and he himself has been wishful for some time past for baptism.

His immediate relations including his own wife had driven him from their camp, but old John and Peter two leading Indians at Wapuskaw and Christian men, befriended him and the second Sunday I was there, he came forward and I had the pleasure of baptizing him. This and the kind Christian counsel, Mr Holmes was so well able to give him in his own language, will, I trust, under God dispel the gloom. You will see from above that Wapuskaw is a stronghold of heathen darkness and superstition and that in planting a Mission there we have chosen a spot that sorely needs the converting, enlightening and humanizing power of the Gospel of Jesus Christ. It is an interesting fact that on the headland on which our Mission now stands, in clearing the bush, Mr Weaver found one of their heathen 'munetokans' or idols; a stump of poplar carved into the rough semblance of a head and shoulders, painted with red earth, and with three black horizontal stripes on the breast. I brought the interesting relic back with me to the landing.

The week before I started we had our little Printing press going almost night and day, as I wanted to take out some little books printed in the Cree Syllabic. In undertaking this work my wish is; firstly - to put into the hands of the Indians small books they can easily carry about with them. Secondly by printing in large type (Pica) syllabics, to enable them to read by the flickering light of their camp fires. Thirdly by omitting the breathings, punctuations, marks of emphasis &c, in general use very helpful to the English learner, but of no use at all to the Indian, to simplify the characters just as they use them in writing their letters. This our first trial, consisted of selected passages of Scripture, Prayers and Hymns. It was a great pleasure to me to hear many of them read the books thus printed without difficulty or hesitation. All were asking for a
copy, but we only gave to those who could read. The syllabarium is attached so that they can teach one another.

On Sunday Feb 16, in the presence of the Indians, I admitted the Rev C. Weaver to Priest's orders assisted by the Rev G. Holmes.

As Mr Weaver becomes more acquainted with their language, I feel sure that he will exercise a strong influence over the Indians and I trust, that the light which is just beginning to gleam in the surrounding darkness, will shine more and more unto the perfect day.

I remain

Yours very sincerely

Athabasca Landing
February 24th 1896.
